story: Bruno Le Maire, France&rsquos finance minister, and his German counterpart Olaf Scholz told reporters plans were &ldquomoving in the right direction to see a common eurozone budget, which they hope to pass by 2021.Le Maire and Scholz hope the a joint budget for all 19 eurozone countries would help stabilise the currency and allow it to more easily absorb economic shocks.However the budget would have to be signed off by all EU countries, some of whom are putting up resistance to the Franco-German alliance.French President Emmanuel Macron has said the &ldquogreater convergence would help the continent&rsquos currency.                Eurozone WARNING: Mario Draghi warns of growth outlook uncertaintyDuring his presidential campaign he argued for such a budget to &ldquoseveral percentage points of GDP, the Financial Times reported.However Dutch finance minister Wopke Hoekstra as well as non-euro states are hesitant as to how the plan would help their economies.Following a meeting of EU finance ministers, Mr Macron said: &ldquoThe lack of convergence between national economies is not sustainable over the long term for a single monetary union.The convergence plan is a central element of Mr Macron&rsquos policy to help the single currency fight future crises and the French president will have been boosted after a number of EU finance ministers backed the plan.French Economy Minister Bruno Le Maire and German Finance Minister Olaf Scholz defend eurozone plan (Image: REUTERS)At a Brussels meeting yesterday, the finance ministers supported draft plans which would operate in the framework of the wider EU budget.Mr Scholz told reporters the scheme would &ldquohelp us to support the convergence of the eurozone and all the other things that are important to our common future.However a number of EU countries, led by the Netherlands, are reluctant to get behind Paris and Berlin&rsquos idea.Denmark, Finland, Poland, Hungary and Austria say they would prefer to see EU spending cut rather than increased. title: space news star milky way supernova explosion earth
story: The binary stars, known as Apep, will one day explode in spectacular fashion (Image: ESOCallingham et al.)Astronomers have found a binary star system &ndash two stars orbiting each other &ndash are whirling around in the depths of the Milky Way at such a speed to trigger one of the most powerful explosions in the universe. The star system is wrapped in an elegant spiral dust cloud, which is what makes it look so &ldquospectacular, experts state. The two stars in question are Wolf-Rayet stars which are among the hottest of all the star types in the universe and the gas being produced is travelling at around 3,400 kilometres per second.                NASA announcement: Space agency teases return to the Moon and Mars                Aliens to be discovered in TWO decades top British scientist claimsNamed Apep, the two stars located around 8,000 light years away from Earth, are emitting vast amounts of hot winds and gasses, which is a sign they are at the end of their lives and will soon explode in a supernova.Professor Paul Crowther, of the University of Sheffield, who was involved in the study which was published in the journal Nature Astronomy, said: It remains a mystery how dust &ndash similar to soot from a candle &ndash forms in such harsh environments&ldquoBut this newly discovered system is the most beautiful case seen to date.Professor Peter Tuthill, co-autgor of the study, added: &ldquoWhen we saw the spiral dust tail we immediately knew we were dealing with a rare and special kind of nebula called a pinwheel.&ldquoThe curved tail is formed by the orbiting binary stars at the centre, which inject dust into the expanding wind creating a pattern like a rotating lawn sprinkler.&ldquoBecause the wind expands so much, it inflates the tiny coils of dust revealing the physics of the stars at the heart of the system.Co-author Dr Benjamin Pope from New York University, said: &ldquoThe key to understanding the bizarre behaviour of the wind lies in the rotation of the central stars.&ldquoWhat we have found in the Apep system is a supernova precursor that seems to be very rapidly rotating, so fast it might be near break-up.&ldquo'The rapid rotation puts Apep into a whole new class. Normal supernovae are already extreme events but adding rotation to the mix can really throw gasoline on the fire.The stars will eventually supernova (Image: )These types of stars have never before been discovered in the Milky Way, and Professor Tuthill says the explosion could be spectacular.He said: &ldquoUltimately, we can't be certain what the future has in store for Apep.&ldquoThe system might slow down enough so it explodes as a normal supernova rather than a gamma-ray burst.&ldquoHowever, in the meantime, it is providing astronomers a ringside seat into beautiful and dangerous physics that we have not seen before in our galaxy.

title: Baltic Sea Anomaly ufo alien ice age glacier
story: Explorers discovered the odd-shaped object on the ocean bed of the Baltic Sea in June 2011.&nbspDubbed the Baltic Sea Anomaly, the object is a 70-metre long (210 feet) strangely-shaped feature that showed up on sonar laying 100 metres (300 feet) beneath the waves.Theories as to what the Anomaly could be have ranged from the interesting to the outrageous, with some claiming it could be part of fleet of crashed UFOs on ocean floor.Some conspiracy theorists even point out it bears a striking resemblance to the Star Wars Millennium Falcon with a steel grey appearance.&nbspThe Baltic Sea Anomaly (Image: YOUTUBE)                Baltic Sea Anomaly is 'ancient monument built by lost civilisation'The Baltic Sea Anomaly (Image: YOUTUBE)Others have claimed it could be the remains of a sunken city lost to the waves years ago.However, a group of ers collected samples from the mysterious entity and gave their finding to scientists who determined that the Baltic Sea Anomaly is simply a glacial deposit.Much of the Baltic Sea was carved out by moving glaciers during the Ice Age.Research undertaken by scientists from Stockholm University has revealed the Baltic Sea Anomaly is leftovers from that process.A map of the Baltic Sea (Image: GOOGLE MAPS)Volker Br&uumlchert, an associate professor of geology at Stockholm University, said: I was surprised when I researched the material I found a great black stone that could be a volcanic rock.&nbsp&ldquoMy hypothesis is that this object, this structure was formed during the Ice Age many thousands of years ago.Because the whole northern Baltic region is so heavily influenced by glacial thawing processes, both the feature and the rock samples are likely to have formed in connection with glacial and postglacial processes.Possibly these rocks were transported there by glaciers.The 26ft tall object was discovered by Swedish explorer Peter Lindberg and his Ocean X team of marine explorers during a e searching for a shipwreck.&nbspDespite the findings from Mr Br&uumlchert, Ocean X maintain that it is not a natural structure.Stefan Hogerborn, part of the Ocean X team, said their electrical equipment stopped working when they got to within 200 metres of the anomaly on the Baltic seabed.MIND-BLOWING signs that aliens exist.                     Getty Images1 of 13The Crop Circles are often believed to be created by aliens, as there is no proper explanation behind this phenomenon.He is quoted by NDTV as saying: &ldquoAnything electric out there &ndash and the satellite phone as well &ndash stopped working when we were above the object.&ldquoAnd then we got away about 200 meters and it turned on again, and when we got back over the object it didn&rsquot work.

title: violent man fractured girlfriends fingers course building better relationships
story: Stephen Field (Image: Marios K. Forsos Cavendish Press (Manchester) Ltd)Stephen Field, 42, left Joanne Beattie with bone fractures and a head wound after he grabbed hold of the wooden door and smashed it against her hand up to four items during a row over household chores.&nbspMiss Beattie who had been holding on to the door frame to stop her falling over backwards on the floor after being shoved by Field, screamed at him to stop but he carried on saying: &ldquoGet out, I will kill you. She fled downstairs but Field, from Little Hulton, near Salford, Greater Manchester caught up with Miss Beattie then slammed her head against a kitchen cupboard.&nbsp                Children who are smacked by parents more likely to become abusive                Angry female MPs demand that &lsquowife-beater&rsquo is suspendedDuring his arrest, he dismissed his violent behaviour as an 'accident.'&nbspMother-of-two, Miss Beattie, said in a statement: I can't understand why he would treat me in this way when he's supposed to love me. I am not willing to put up with this behaviour and I am worried he has anger issues and I am worried he could assault me in the future.I am worried he could influence my daughter and she is moving towards and abusive relationship as this is what she has witnessed and she believes this type of behaviour is normal.&nbspAt Manchester Crown Court, Field admitting to two charges of assault occasioning actual bodily harm and two charges of criminal damage but escaped with a two year community order after he claimed he seen the error in his ways and needed professional help.The couple (Image: Joanne Beattie Cavendish Press)He will now attend a counselling programme, which it is claimed will help Field get a better understanding of himself plus find and build on his strengths to improve their lifestyle and relationships. The court heard the pair is now back together.The Manchester Crown Court heard Field had met Miss Beattie six years ago and later moved in with her and her two children aged 15 and 16.&nbspBut prosecutor Simone Flynn said: Soon afterwards his behaviour became increasingly aggressive. On this particular occasion on July 27th last year she was at home with the defendant in the bedroom, and her two children were also in the house.An argument broke out between her and the defendant and she was shoved by the defendant with both hands in the chest area, and she staggered backwards. As she fell backwards she grabbed the door frame with her left hand fingers. But the defendant grabbed hold of the door and slammed it, which closed on her fingers, three to four times.On the first slam, she screamed and shouted at him. This didn't stop him and he continued to slam the door and she heard him shout: get out, I will kill you.&nbsp&ldquoShe headed downstairs and she would later discover that she sustained a fractured finger. Twenty minutes later she returned to the bedroom to remove her clothes.The defendant begins throwing the clothes at her so she goes downstairs to the kitchen. Standing in the kitchen she leaned against the kitchen counter. The defendant then walked straight up to her and shoved her backwards, again with both hands in the chest area.The force used caused her head to fly backwards hitting the kitchen cupboard, accumulating in a long cut to the scalp, on the hairline above the right ear.Mother-of-two Joanne Beattie (Image: Joanne Beattie Cavendish Press)Police were called to the address, but the defendant had left. She was taken to Bolton Royal Hospital where her cut to her head was glued, and her finger was operated in, and a pin was inserted into the bone to ensure it was set properly.&nbspThe couple reconciled and Field moved back on July 3 this year, another argument erupted between the two, and he went on the rampage around the property.&nbspMiss Flynn added: He punched the walls and doors of the property and one door had to be replaced, costing &pound300. He also caused damage to the bedroom and smashed the TV by throwing it outside.There was further damage to the shed and damage to the rear patio door costing &pound700. Miss Beattie's 16 year old daughter heard the commotion and said she knew the relationship between them was volatile. She said that the defendant can snap, he is really loud and seems really angry.Mr Field repeatedly slammed his bedroom door against his girlfriend's fingers (Image: Marios K. Forsos Cavendish Press (Manchester) Ltd)She said she opened her bedroom door when she heard the commotion and her mother came straight in telling her to call the police. She said she watched him go into the shed and she saw him get a hammer and start smashing the door.Field was arrested on July 11 but initially denied wrongdoing. A total of 65 offences are recorded on his criminal record including offences of ABH, robbery with an imitation firearm and criminal damage.Whilst he was on bail for his attacks upon Miss Beattie he attended her address twice in two days.&nbspOn the first occasion he claimed he wanted to pick up some clothes, but a row broke out and he threw her mobile phone at her.&nbspThen on the second he got access to her Miss Beattie's home and smashed a mug during another argument.In mitigation defence lawyer Richard Dawson said: The past is the past, they remain in that relationship and wish for that relationship to continue. He has, at least, some degree of insight into these problems. These underlying issues need to be addressed so they can be tackled.If he was to be sent to custody, that will do little if anything to tackle these underlying issues. He needs constructive help in regards to tackling this domestic and violent behaviour. He does have underlying anger management difficulties. It is highly unlikely that will be tackled in a custodial environment.There is frustration, there was tension and an element of hostility. He will not be able to address these issues if he does not receive the support and help he needs, and he needs the correct approach in order to tackle these underlying issues, and in my submission, sending him to custody is not the correct approach.&nbspThe couple is now back together (Image: Joanne Beattie Cavendish Press)Sentencing Judge Suzanne Goddard QC told Field: You have got a bad record and all that I have read about you shows you have serious anger management problems and that you don't know how to react appropriately to the stresses of life and relationships.There is never and excuse for shutting a door on someone's fingers. You say it was an accident, but you don't really understand exactly what problem you have got. On the the hand, the relationship is still on going and the reparation is that you are remorseful.With a degree of concern and because of the support of your family and partner, I am persuaded to take the option suggested by the probationary service. But I am going to keep a close eye on you.Field was also ordered to complete 25 days of rehabilitation requirement activities, attend a Building Better relationships programme and will complete 100 hours unpaid work.&nbspHe was also issued with a restraining order prohibiting him from molesting Miss Beattie for a period of five years.Boses behind the BBR course says it is designed to promote lifelong changes in behaviours and attitudes which, in the past, have resulted in male service users being convicted of intimate partner violence.&nbsp

title: brexit news latest deal general election 2018 theresa may andrew bridgen
story: Andrew Bridgen predicts Prime Minister Theresa May will deliver a General Election in the spring, adding the Conservatives have no majority in the House of Commons without the DUP&rsquos support. Speaking on Talkradio, the Tory MP said: &ldquoThe Government is under huge threat now, the withdrawal agreement as it&rsquos drafted, as Dominic Raab said in his resignation, is a threat to the union. Our confidence and supply partners are the DUP, and they are obviously very concerned about the union. We are at risk now of losing their support, they&rsquove made it clear that their support is for the Conservative Party not Theresa May.                Brexit news: Mark Carney BACKS Theresa May as BoE boss issues WARNING&ldquoLast night they did not vote with the Government, without their vote we can get no legislation through, that means that we are heading for a General Election, which is exactly what Jeremy Corbyn wants.&ldquoPerhaps in return for Labour&rsquos support for voting through the withdrawal bill, perhaps Theresa May is going to deliver Labour a General Election in the spring.Radio host Julia Hartley-Brewer then challenged the Brexiteer: &ldquoWhy does there have to be a General election? I mean if you cannot get the DUP&rsquoS support, the DUP have made it quite clear it&rsquos about Theresa May&rsquos withdrawal agreement that they&rsquore concerned.&ldquoThey would give their support back to the Conservatives if they were delivering the Brexit they were promised, as part of that confidence and supply agreement.Brexit news: Andrew Bridgen warned the Government is under huge threat (Image: TalkradioBBC)&ldquoIn which case there does not have to be a General Election, which you know perfectly well, no Conservative MP&rsquos going to vote for, which they&rsquod have to do to overrule the fixed-term Parliament Act, in which the issue is simply getting another leader.Mr Bridgen responded: &ldquoIndeed, but we need to do that, we need to get to 48 letters and push through with the confidence motion, but without the DUP&rsquos support we have no majority in the House of Commons.&ldquoNo legislation can get through the House of Commons on a vote, that&rsquos a paralysed Government, that&rsquos not going to go down well.Conservative rebels had stated there would be a vote on Mrs May&rsquos leadership as early as Tuesday, but this has been stalled due to their inability to reach the required number of letters.In total, 48 letters need to be handed into Sir Graham Brady before a vote is called. Now, it appears a no-confidence vote could be avoided until after the parliamentary vote on the Prime Minister&rsquos proposed Brexit withdrawal agreement.Last week, the European Research Group of Tory Eurosceptics said that the 48 letters would be handed in by Monday.Simon Clarke, one of the MPs who publicly announced he had submitted his letter, also said Mrs May faced a &ldquocrucial day on Monday.However, Eurosceptic MP Steve Baker said: Anyone who thinks that the moment of danger has passed has succumbed to spin. This is a process, not a moment.

title: bbc tv licence fee consultation licence fee cost
story: Options could include scrapping the free licence fee for over-75s (Image: Anthony DevlinPA Wire)The Government-funded scheme, which provides free TV licences to older viewers, comes an end in June 2020.&nbspBBC chairman Sir David Clementi said the Board, which will make the final call, does not underestimate the significance of the decision, its implications for the BBC and its audiences. Options could include the BBC copying the Government scheme and paying for it.                BBC BLASTED: David Davis furious at plans to cut OAP free TV licenses But, it writes, that could cost around a fifth of our budget - the equivalent to what we spend today on all of BBC Two, BBC Three, BBC Four, the BBC News Channel, CBBC and CBeebies.That would mean over 75s would not have to pay, as at present, but we think it would fundamentally change the BBC because of the scale of service cuts we would need to make.Another option could be scrapping the free licence fee for over-75s.This would mean the BBC would not have to make significant cuts to BBC services, but would have an impact on those over 75s, particularly poorer pensioners, who currently do not pay, it says.The BBC says it could also reform the scheme in various ways including discounting the cost of a licence fee for older people, raising the age from 75 to 80, or introducing means-testing.The broadcaster said that it was not backing any particular option over another today, as it opened a three-month consultation.Its Board hopes to make a decision by the summer.BBC director-general Tony Hall said: This is an important decision.The scheme will include discounting the cost of a licence fee for older people (Image: )We have set out a range of options - each has merits and consequences, with implications for the future of the BBC, and for everyone, including older people.We need to hear views to help the BBC make the best and fairest decision.Sir David Clementi said: We will listen to their views and balance all the options and arguments before making a decision.Shadow media secretary Tom Watson called for the Government to step in and save TV licences for the elderly.TV licence for over 75s (Image: )The Government should never have privatised welfare policy in this way. Labour opposed this move from the start, he said.The prospect of elderly people losing their free TV licences makes a mockery of the claim that austerity is over, he said.It is expected that free TV licences would cost &pound745 million a year by 202122.Economic consultants have said the cost of providing a free BBC service to over-75s would exceed &pound1 billion a year in a decade's time.The Board of the giant broadcaster is hoping to make a decision by the summer (Image: Oli ScarffGetty Images)The corporation took over the cost from the Government of providing free TV licences for over-75s as part of its charter renewal negotiations.A spokesman for the Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport said: We know people across the country value television as a way to stay connected with the world.The BBC will take on responsibility for free licences for the over-75s from 2020 and it is right that they've confirmed no decisions will be taken until the public have been fully consulted.We've been clear that we would want and expect them to continue with this important concession.Ultimately it is the BBC's responsibility to ensure its substantial licence fee income is used effectively to deliver fully for UK audiences.

story: The DUP, which props up Theresa May&rsquos government, failed to back the Prime Minister on a number of amendments to its Finance Bill and instead supported an amendment proposed by the Labour Party in protest against the Brexit deal.Speaking to Express, the DUP&rsquos Brexit spokesman Sammy Wilson warned that without the DUP, the Government would have sold Britain out in Brexit talks.He said: &ldquoHad we not had the influence that the last election gave us that the Government would have simply proceeded with the plan which the European Union had for our future and would have caved in.&ldquoEven with the necessity of our support, the Government has still chased after the EU agenda. I mean, this is the sickening thing.                Jacob Rees-Mogg reveals WHEN Theresa May will face no confidence vote&ldquoThe Prime Minister of the United Kingdom is more interested in the demands of the EU than in the requirements of the UK when it has come to this backstop arrangement, knowing full well that what the European Union is suggesting would lead to the break up of the United Kingdom.The Irish backstop,&nbspa last&nbspresort option to prevent a hard border on the island of Ireland, has been agreed between the UK.The agreed backstop would see Northern Ireland remain aligned to elements of the EU&rsquos single market if no solution to the issue is found before the end of the Brexit transition on December 2020.The backstop agreement would also keep the whole of the UK in the EU customs union until both parties&nbspagree&nbspit is no longer needed.Brexit news: Sammy Wilson says Theresa May has chased after EU agenda (Image: &bull)Mr Wilson continued: &ldquoTo say that &lsquooh it is only a temporary arrangement, it might never be used, it is only an insurance policy&rsquo. If it was never going to be used then you don&rsquot put it in.&ldquoYou simply say to the European Union &lsquolet&rsquos get in place the arrangement to facilitate trade across the border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic and, anyhow, the issues which have to be dealt with on that border have to be dealt with at Dover and Calais.&ldquoThey have to be dealt with at Felixstowe and Antwerp or whatever other interfaces there are because the same issues arise.The DUP&rsquos decision to withdraw the support for the Government on Monday effectively breached the &ldquoconfidence and supply agreement between the DUP and Conservatives.The deal binds 10 DUP MPs to support the Government on all motions of confidence and on the Queen's Speech the budget finance bills.The DUP&rsquos opposition could potentially harm the Prime Minister's authority as it puts her parliamentary majority in jeopardy.The move could also motivate hesitant Eurosceptic MPs to submit their letters of no-confidence against the Prime Minister.At least 24 MPs say they have submitted letters to the chairman of 1922 Committee, but the total is still well short of the 48 required to trigger a secret ballot.

This is a new set of arguments because the choices we are faced with now are completely different to the choices that people were presented with the second time around.&ldquoIt&rsquos hard to see how any of this about a vote of no confidence in Theresa May would make any difference to the fact that we are not going to realistically going to be able to renegotiate a withdrawal between now and March.&ldquoWe would be facing a no deal, and that is not what people who voted Brexit necessarily voted for.&ldquoThe polls show that, people who voted Brexit are beginning to change their mind.Conservative rebels had stated there would be a vote on Theresa May&rsquos leadership as early as today, but this has been stalled due to their inability to reach the required number of letters.In total, 48 letters need to be handed into Sir Graham Brady before a vote is called. title: teenager pregnant fish philippines ovarian cyst
story: Teenager: Kimberly Robles Besinal (Image: ViralPress)Kimberly Robles Besinal , 17, from the remote island in Albay, the Philippines, began experiencing stomach pains last June.&nbspAs her tummy started to swell her family angrily accused her of having a secret lover.&nbspIn a bizarre twist, they forced Kimberly to undergo an ultrasound scan, which appeared to show a strange creature with fish-like eyes and a mouth in her belly.&nbsp                Teenager&rsquos joy as &lsquocyst&rsquo turns out to be baby boyThe pictures - combined with a Filippino bygone belief and the youngster's love of swimming without underwear - caused the family to accused her of having sex with a FISH.&nbspAs an ancient Filipino superstition suggests, Kimberley&rsquos family believed she was carrying a mythological serpent in her tummy and shunned her.But after a year passed no baby had materialised, so doctors checked again. In 2017, Kimberley's body&nbspweight increased by 10 kilos, from 40 to 50kgs, which medics have put down to the cyst.&nbspKimberly is now trying to raise money for the operation to surgically remove the large cyst.&nbspShe said: I am having a hard time breathing and my chest feels tight. I feel like someone is choking me.Kimberley's ultrasound scan,which showed what her family believed to be a mythological serpent (Image: ViralPress)My family thought I was pregnant, but I had no boyfriend. They then believed I was pregnant by a mythical creature because I used to like swimming in the ocean without panties.Her father, Pablo Robles, said the family now understood that Kimberly had never been pregnant - either from a local boy or a fish.&nbspThe belief comes from an ancient myth, which suggests that when a woman on her menstruation swims in the sea without underwear, organisms can enter her vagina causing her to fall pregnant with a mythical creature.&nbspPablo said: At first, I told her to tell me the truth if she is pregnant. I was angry but now I believe her.&nbspThe teenager is actually suffering from an ovarian cyst (Image: ViralPress)Despite the medical evidence, Kimberley's grandmother and cousin still believe the growth in her belly is that of a mythical fish from the 'Gumaliw' folklore.Locals on the tiny island of Manaet in the Bacacay region believe that women should stay out of the ocean for up to five days after their monthly period.Kimberley's cousin, Amada Robles, said: Kimberley likes swimming in the sea, just a few walks away from our house. I always scold her for doing that especially on her menstruation day, but she is so hard-headed.&nbspDr Massachusette Fernandez, the obstetrician-gynecologist who is treating Kimberly, said: The scan really resembles a fish, but it's not. She has an ovarian cyst. It is impossible to have a fish inside her ovaries.&nbsp

title: brexit deal purgatory leavers remainers
story: It’s quite a challenge, but let’s have a go.Suppose, for the sake of argument, that Britain ended up with all the costs and obligations of European Union membership, but with no voice, no vote and no veto.Suppose we had to accept all the EU’s rules — on technical standards, on environmental protection, on labour law — but no longer had any say over what those rules should be. Suppose we had to submit to a trade and tarf regime designed solely to benefit the other .I hope both sides could agree that such an outcome would be the worst of all possible worlds. And yet, that is where we appear to have ended up.First, under the transition, we shall explicitly be non-voting members for two years.As Brussels has spelt out with brutal clarity, the only change will be that Britain loses its Commissioner, its MEPs and its vote in Council.Then, under the backstop, that status, or something very like it, will be imposed on us in semi-perpetuity.Surely no one — Remain or Leave — can favour such an outcome.I have been arguing since polling day for moderation.I was prepared to accept any compromise, including European Free Trade Association and including Chequers, provided it restored the supremacy of our laws.But the purgatory that now beckons is surely, by any definition, worse than either staying or leaving.From the start, our objective was simply to reach a deal — any deal.Our negotiators, shell-shocked by the referendum result, approached the talks in a spirit of damage limitation.They never seriously contemplated walking away, and the other side smelt their desperation.To be fair, our officials were not helped by the noises coming out of Westminster.How would you expect EU negotiators to react when senior British politicians urge them to hang tough and force a second referendum We might view Tony Blair, John Major and Nick Clegg as has-beens but, believe me, they are seen in Brussels as men of influence.So we fell into a pattern. Britain would make some new concession in the hope of unlocking a deal.Then Brussels would pocket the concession and demand more and — incredibly — British Remainers would cheer.The UK agreed to hand over more money than was due accepted the EU’s absurd and illogical sequencing made an unconditional security guarantee offered to copy EU standards and promised not to be more competitive than its neighbours.Each time, the EU brusquely demanded “more movement”. Each time, Britain rushed to comply.Which brings us to where we are — facing colonial rule from Brussels, of the sort the EU imposed on Bosnia following the Yugoslav war.I am not one of those Brexiteers who half-favoured no deal all along.On the contrary, I was proposing moderation even before the vote, and have repeated that call many times since.But, paradoxically, our reluctance to countenance no deal has made such an outcome likelier.We have reached the point where the terms on offer are less attractive than either a World Trade Organization-based Brexit or a second referendum. This last point is critical.I suspect that two contradictory arguments will now be wheeled out before wavering MPs.Europhiles will be told that the deal, backstop and all, is better than “crashing out” on WTO terms.Conversely, Eurosceptics will be told thatthey don’t approve the deal, Parliament might vote to extend Article , thus imperilling Brexit.These two lines of argument can’t both be true, of course and, in reality, neither of them is.We’re invited to believe thatBoris Johnson and Jo Johnson, from opposite ends of the Brexit spectrum, both oppose the deal, it can’t be too bad. In fact, both Johnsons oppose it because it is a lamentable failure of statecraft.Boris was no Brexit headbanger: He came out for Leave only after the EU refused to give David Cameron any powers back.And Jo is no Remoaner: He has spent two years in Government trying to deliver a reasonable Brexit. If neither of them will back the deal, that tells us something.There is still time — just — to recover our position.As things stand, the backstop has no legal force.The moment it finds its way into a treaty, it will be binding. If any MPs oppose the current approach, now is their chance to act. There won’t be another.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: time for decades of eu lies to end
story: Britain is a eurosceptic nation. In the s, Ted Heath and Harold Wilson both knew we would baulk at belonging to a Common Market that robbed us of our national independence.So they hid its true purpose — “ever closer union”, leading to a superstate with one currency. The public was reassured our sovereignty would not be surrendered to any meaningful degree.The Tory and Labour leaders both knew this was a lie. But they kept quiet when signing us up in  and when holding the first referendum in .Voters were betrayed from the start. And the pattern was set.In  John Major signed the Maastricht Treaty, creating the EU, without risking the public vote that saw it initially rejected by the Danes and Irish.In  Tony Blair — who now shamelessly praises fork-tongued civil ­servants for hoodwinking eurosceptic ministers — feared he would lose a referendum on handing new powers to the EU. So he refused to hold it.His successor Gordon Brown, never big on honesty when a lie served him better, pretended this Lisbon Treaty was too insignicant to bother voters with.The EU is founded on deceit. “When it becomes serious, you have to lie,” says President Jean-Claude Juncker. Voters are bullied into reversing inconvenient referendums or denied a say at all.And so to Mrs May, the Brexit deal her Cabinet agreed last night and the revealing EU leak yesterday which makes crystal-clear Brussels’ intentions to keep us in its vice-like grip for ever.That plan being to lock us into its Customs Union for all time, unable to make our own trade deals, powerlessly swallowing its orders and obeying its rules.Our Government knows we cannot legally escape this central pillar of the EU — which we voted to “leave”, remember — without consent from Brussels that it will never give.This is not some minor afterthought, to be bargained away, which is why MPs rejected it in July. It is crucial to the reclaiming of our sovereignty which a .million majority including many Sun readers, voted for in .It is crucial to our post-Brexit prosperity. It looks crucial, too, to whether the deal lives or dies. Yet, knowing exactly what the EU intends for us, the PM still brazenly insisted yesterday that we WILL make our own trade deals.How, Mrs May  We cannot. You surely know it.Do not kid yourself no one is paying attention. The public has been sold a pup again and again. It has had enough.Come clean with Britain. This deal is not wholly without merit. But let us see it for what it is.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: im a celebrity noel edmonds
story: With or without his rehab ­certicate. Preferably driving John Barrowman’s jeep.But definitely presenting I’m A Celebrity . . . Get Me Out Of Here! which kicked off, on Sunday night, with Dec hosting and Holly ­Willoughby hanging around like a competition winner.An arrangement that would be unsustainable in other years. I’m prepared to cut the  series some slack, though, for two reasons.First, it is purely a temporary pairing and, second, ITV has promised me Noel Edmonds, who shouldn’t just have been the first one in the camp, he should’ve been choppered in about eight years ago, when the contestants started all this “bonding” rubbish, which has ruined more series than I care to remember.Oh, what some of them could’ve done with a one-man feud generator like Noel, whose Wikipedia entry will give you a fair idea of his inner turmoil even before you get to the bit where he says: “When I die, my energy willto where it came from.” Ilford He’s also got a le-size mannequin doll called Candice, who accompanies him everywhere and would be a more than welcome replacement for a few of the camp mates, who’ve got a bit of a Rita Who and Knob Too feel about them this year.The knob part of that equation, fairly obviously, is all-singing, all-dancing John Barrowman “MBE” , who described himself as “fabulous”, “an icon” and “down-to-earth” within the space of one sentence, on Sunday, and was wrong on every count.He also hit on the yacht waiter, using one of his dance moves.“It’s a pas de bourrée. Kick ball, change and turn. Can you do that ”“I’m not allowed.”Not even the kick balls bit Shame. He needs someone to calm him down.Although, as horrendous as it must be to live with, I don’t mind Barrowman on I’m A Celeb, as the show does need a massive irritant to get under everyone’s skin.On similar grounds, I also welcome EastEnders’ Rita Simons, who looks like she might have a tantrum or two in her, Nick Knowles, who will be incapable of stling his Sir Galahad complex, and Harry Redknapp, just because he’s Harry Redknapp.Of the others The public jury’s probably still out on Emily Atack and The Chase Governess Anne Hegerty, who “used to be a Brownie”, as well as eating a lot of a drag.It usually does, of course, as the celebs haven’t yet let their guard drop.But, in this instance it meant the spotlight fell on Holly Willoughby, and you quickly realised Dec hasn’t had to story: Speaking in the Commons she rubbished a UN special report on extreme poverty in Britain branding it “wholly inappropriate”.The former Home Secretary - ed to the front bench after a six month hiatus - accused UN special rapporteur Philip Alston of being “extraordinarily political”.It came after he published a preliminary report condemning the Government’s attitude towards poverty.He wrote: “Government policies have inflicted great misery unnecessarily, especially on the working poor, on single mothers struggling against mighty odds, on people with disabilities who are already marginalised, and on millions of children.”Ms Rudd said she read the report over the weekend saying he had “discredited” his own findings. title: termite mounds 4000 years old found amazon brazil
story: The piles of earth, which are as old as the pyramids, cover an area bigger than Britain and are visible from space.The mounds are not nests but the product of a slow and steady excavation of interconnected underground tunnels, according to a study of soil samples.The insects deposited huge quantities of dug out soil to create around  million cone-shaped mounds, each about .ft  tall and .ft wide.Together the mounds cover an area of , square kilometres, signicantly greater than England, Scotland and Wales combined.And the termites activities over thousands of years produced enough excavated soil to fill Wembley Stadium , times over. At ground level, they are largely hidden from view among the thorny scrub caatinga forests unique to the semi-desert region - but they show up on Google Earth satellite images.Study leader Professor Stephen Martin, from the University of Salford, said: These mounds were formed by a single termite species that excavated a massive network of tunnels to allow them to access dead leaves to eat safely and directly from the forest floor.The amount of soil excavated is over  cubic kilometres, equivalent to , great pyramids of Giza, and represents one of the biggest structures built by a single insect species.The scientists collected soil samples from the centres of  mounds and used dating technology to estimate their age.The results, published in the journal Current Biology, showed the mounds were between  and , years old.Termite mounds have a complex inner structure with numerous shafts and tunnels that serve as a ventilation system for underground nests.The constructions investigated by the scientists are not abandoned ancient relics.Their builders, all members of the termite species Syntermes dirus, still inhabit large colonies incorporating as many as  mounds, the study found.Prof Martin added: Its incredible that, in this day and age, you can find an unknown biological wonder of this sheer size and age still existing, with the occupants still present.Many questions about the termite colonies remain unanswered, said the researchers.For instance, attempts to explore the colonies with a fibre optic scope had failed to locate a single royal chamber housing the termite queen.The mounds were also distributed in a strangely regular way that did not appear to be driven by aggressive encounters between neighbouring colonies.

title: vape at work mps say
story: According to the All-Party Parliamentary Group for Vaping , employers should provide designated indoor vaping areas - including in the Houses of Parliament.They want vaping to be more acceptable around the workplace with proper vaping policies for businesses and public places to be put in place in a bid to tackle misunderstandings about the practice.The group believes that guidelines for reasonable vaping etiquette should be drawn up and that all outside areas should be available to vapers unless theres a legitimate safety or professional reason to stop it.APPGV chairman Mark Pawsey said that Britains current anti-vaping culture created a  impression among the public that passive vaping was as harmful as passive smoking.Indeed, this lack of understanding was very evident in Parliament itself, a place many will look to for an example.There are only two designated vaping locations, and despite being a member for eight years, I still have no idea where either of these locations are, he said.Both of the sites are outside and given the size of the Parliament Estate could be a signicant distance away from an employee or visitors location, MPs stated.It comes after council bosses in Dundee banned staff from vaping anywhere during work hours - eventheyre off the premises.While the British Heart Foundation doesnt advise non-smokers to start smoking e-cigs, Public Health England estimates that theyre  per cent less harmful than regular cigarettes - thanks to the fact that they dont create toxic tobacco smoke.Hazel Cheeseman, Director of Policy for Action on Smoking and Healthtold The Sun: “Public health organisations like ASH and PHE have long said that we need clear policies that distinguish between vaping and smoking.When organisations treat them the same, without being clear that e-cigarettes are a much less harmful alternative, it fuels public misunderstanding and makes it less likely that smokers will switch and protect their health.Whether people choose to allow vaping inside the workplace will depend on inidual circumstances.But what is crucial is that employees understand that vaping is not as harmful as smoking and any restrictions are not about health but about courtesy in the working environment.A report by PHE published in  found that e-cigs were so much less harmful than smoking, that they could pave the way for the real game changer in regards to helping prisons go smoke-free.A project to get prisons in England to implement smoke-free policies is now fully underway, with vaping playing a critical role.Prior to the project starting, around , prisoners were buying tobacco.Today, prison canteens sell over , vaping protects to , prisoners - suggesting a signicant reduction in harm.According to Public Health Matters, . per cent of adults in England smoke tobacco. In prison,  per cent of people smoke.If vaping really is  per cent safer, that could see a massive reduction in the , smoke-related deaths we see in England every year.Daniel Pryor, Head of Programmes at the Adam Smith Institute told The Sun: Britain’s businesses should make it as easy as possible for smokers to switch to e-cigs, which are at least  per cent safer than cigarettes.The latest scientic evidence shows no risks from so-called passive vaping, so letting vapers use their devices considerately indoors is a no-brainer for public health and personal freedom.Not having to pop out for a puff in the pouring rain could make the dference between someone stopping smoking using an e-cig and their quit attempt ending in failure.And stopping could make the dference between living a long and healthy le, or dying early of cancer.The New Nicotine Alliancehas welcomed the Parliamentary report, with its chair, Sarah Jakes, saying: The Parliamentary estate becoming vape-friendly would send a strong message to other employers and venue owners that vapers should be encouraged, not harassed, and would help to educate the public that vapers are simply former smokers doing something that is good for their health.There are currently . million vapers in the UK, . million of whom have quit smoking entirely using e-cigarettes.This has contributed to the rate of smoking prevalence plummeting, but many smokers are still hesitant due to misperceptions surrounding vaping.More liberal workplace policies can have the dual benefit of correcting these misperceptions while also providing a more encouraging environment for vapers to prevent relapse, as well as for smokers considering vaping instead.Back in August, MPs called for e-cigs to be made free on the NHS as a key weapon in the health services stop-smoking arsenal.

title: tiger farm czech republic fur stock cubes
story: The secret raid - dubbed Operation Trophy - was the culmination of years of work by agencies working together across the Czech Republic.Sickened inspectors found one freshly killed tiger and a chest freezer stuffed full of rotting remains when they swooped on the lucrative operation in Prague.They later discovered that bones turned into stock cubes were worth up an incredible £ per gram - which is the equivalent of £, per ounce.Inidual claws ripped from the cats powerful paws are worth nearly £ and a full pelt can fetch up to £, on the Czech black market.The demand for traditional medicines containing tiger products was driven in part by the countrys Vietnamese population.Those involved in the operation now fear the discovery points to a wider problem in Europe, reports the .At a press conference, Robert Šlachta from the Customs Directorate uncovered more details about the horrying case.“The tiger we discovered was shot in the eye and in the neck, so that the skin would stay intact and could be sold on the black market, he said.The cooking of the tiger meat took five to twelve days and all parts of the animal, including the pelts, teeth or claws, were intended for commercial purposes.”The investigation - which started five years ago - was carried out in close cooperation with the Czech Environmental Inspectorate.Its head, Erik Geuss, says the illegal trade in tigers has rapidly become a growing problem in the country.“In recent years, we have observed an increase in the illegal export of tigers and other felines from the Czech Republic, he revealed.This is because there is quite a large Asian community living in the Czech Republic and there is a substantial demand for tiger products in that region.“There are currently around  tigers registered by CITES in the Czech Republic but only around  of them live in zoological gardens.And while tigers kept in zoos live to around the age of , those kept by private breeders only live around five years.”Pavla Rihova, the lead environmental inspector on the scene, said she had never seen anything like it.“I have been working for the inspectorate  years … but the situation there was really horrible, she said.If you can imagine: an old freezer, without electricity, full of meat and dead bodies, in the garden for two years. Absolutely incredible.”In a shed next to the house officers found a freshly killed tiger, shot through the neck so as not to damage its valuable pelt.In the same room was a heavy duty cooking pot on a gas hob, filled with the unidentied meat and bones of animals.The trail of evidence began in , when Czech customs inspectors found a bag of tiger bones in the van of a Vietnamese man.A few months later, the skeletons of two tigers were found concealed within a set of loudspeakers being exported to Hanoi.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: vapers popcorn lung ecigarettes
story: Flavoured e-cigarettes are increasing in popularity, prompting warnings they are encouraging teenagers to take up vaping and getting them hooked on nicotine.Last week American company Juul announced it would temporarily pull some flavoured e-cigarettes from stores in the US until shops agree to adopt new age restrictions to ensure customers are at least  before they buy an e-cigarette.Juul was set to sell e-cigarettes at , Sainsburys stores in the UK from November .But its not just underage smoking that poses a risk with e-cigarettes - a chemical found in some flavours have been linked to an irreversible lung condition.Diacetyl, a chemical that creates a buttery flavour, has been linked to a condition called obliterative bronchiolitis, dubbed popcorn lung because of the high levels of disease found in workers from factories that used the chemical in microwave popcorn.The condition causes causes inflammation, scarring and constriction of the bronchioles –the tubes through which air passes from your nose or mouth to your lungs.Diacetyl is used in a number of buttery flavours like cupcake and candy floss.Over time the inflammation associated with popcorn lung causes the tissues and airways in the organ to scar and narrow, leaving sufferers with breathing dficulties.The symptoms may seem subtle to begin with, so can be easy to over look, they include wheezing, a dry cough, shortness of breath, unexplained exhaustion, rapid breathing, persistent skin, eye or mouth irritation.According to a Hard University in , Hard University, there is a direct link between diacetyl in e-cigarettes and popcorn lung.The study tested  types of flavoured e-cigs – specically choosing flavours that would be appealing to young people.Out of the  flavours tested,  of them had above the recommended level of diacetyl, leading scientists to conclude that urgent action is recommended to further evaluate this potentially widespread exposure via flavoured e-cigarettes.A pamphlet released by the US Surgeon Generals office also warned of the dangers of diacetyl in e-cigs, linking it to popcorn lung.But the Hard University analysis was done on e-cigarettes in the US, where diacetyl is allowed in vaping products.In the UK the chemical is banned, so its unlikely vapes youve bought here will contain the chemical.According to a Public Health Englandblog, Public Health Matters, its a myth that smoking e-cigarettes puts users at risk of popcorn lung.But that doesnt mean flavours containing the chemical cant be bought online from the US.One of the most commonly held concerns is that e-cigarettes might cause popcorn lung, PHE said.This came about because some flavourings used in e-liquids to provide a buttery flavour contain the chemical diacetyl, which at very high levels of exposure has been associated with the serious lung disease bronchiolitis obliterans.The condition gained its popular name because it was initially observed among workers in a popcorn factory.However, diacetyl is banned as an ingredient from e-cigarettes and e-liquids in the UK.It had been detected in some e-liquid flavourings in the past, but at levels hundreds of times lower than in cigarette smoke. Even at these levels, smoking is not a major risk factor for this rare disease.MPs have previously called for e-cigarettes to be free on the NHS as a stop smoking device.E-cigarettes are less harmful than conventional smoking and the two should not be treated as the same, according to a report by the Science and Technology Committee .Public Health England estimates suggest e-cigarettes are at least  per cent less harmful than smoking.Around . million Brits use e-cigarettes, and its thought , use them as an aid to stop smoking.A report from the All-Party Parliamentary Group for Vapingtoday sugguests employers should provide designated indoor vaping areas - including in the Houses of Parliament.They want vaping to be more acceptable around the workplace with proper vaping policies for businesses and public places to be put in place in a bid to tackle misunderstandings about the practice

story: These images show the unfurnished interior of the  sq ft portable home, with its wood-led walls and floors, as well as stairs leading to the second floor.Other shots show the tiny home from outside in its normal guise and with the roof extended to allow access upstairs.The Devasa, as it’s known, is legally towable and once parked up and expanded, can sleep a family of four.On the first level there is a kitchen, a smallish living room and a bathroom, with the bedrooms on the second level.The Devasa’s roof is raised and lowered by four motorized screw jacks located on each corner.This can be done using a car battery via the towing bar but should the battery die or the motor fail, it is possible to operate the jacks manually.The Devasa is work of the family-owned house designers behind Tiny House NYC and is currently on sale for around £,.We are a family-owned-and-operated business based in New York City, says the company.Our mission is to provide financial freedom for those seeking to go tiny.The world has changed a lot since the great recession, and from that tragedy came the need for alternative solutions to combat rising home costs, debt and stagnant wages.Many see the tiny house movement as a lestyle. It is certainly that, and we believe it also allows people to take control of their lives.By empowering others, we hope to create a more affordable and sustainable world for today and the future.The portable tiny house measures . ft long and . ft tall when in the lowered position and  ft tall when raised, offering impressive . ft high ceilings upstairs.

story: They say searches for serious health conditions have increased by thousands of percentage points over the last three years.UK search volumes for terms such as how to know chest pains are serious have risen by , per cent from  to , analysis of Google data has found.And searches for keywords such as sciatica, acne and IBS plus the word treatment are now searched more than , times on average every year since .Stomach ache and aching legs were also found to top online searches, with an average of , and , searches yearly since .GP near me was googled , times between January and August alone this year.Hannah Sims, product manager for Perkbox Medical, which commissioned the research, said: “The NHS has been looking after the health of the nation for  years now.“It’s a wonderful system, but it isn’t without its challenges, particularly in primary care.“Currently, over one million people a week in the UK struggle to get themselves seen by a doctor when they need it.“GP surgeries tend to only be open during the usual working hours and are stretched to fit everyone in, pushing appointment waiting times to around two weeks.“Similarly, the average health insurance premium in the UK costs £,.The NHS lists hypochondria as health anxiety. According to the health organisation, it is commonly listed as having the following symptoms:Anxiety itself can cause symptoms like headaches or a racing heartbeat, and you may mistake these for signs of illness.“On top of that, there’s the admin involved with sorting it all out – wading through pages of jargon, comparing dferent, often confusing policies, conducting a full census of your staff and making big decisions about what you can and can’t afford to cover.It’s not an easy world to navigate in, and it’s no wonder busy employers and HR leaders back away.”The research also found that the number of Brits self-diagnosing themselves using Google is on the rise.How to knowchest pains are serious , was among the most searched terms with , average searches from January - August this year.How to get rid of back pain , received , average searches in the same period, and how to get rid of stomach pain , garnered , average searches.Sims added: “Many of these symptoms account for key causes of absenteeism at work, which costs the UK economy £billion per year.“And it makes sense, when waiting times are often long and employers aren’t financially able to provide their staff with an alternative route to see a doctor, people naturally look for a quick fix solution, googling their symptoms and getting some rest from home, or, worse, falling victims to ‘presenteeism’ at work.“Perkbox Medical is the first private healthcare product designed to focus specically on the areas where the NHS is particularly challenged - the most obvious one being primary care .“It’s an affordable solution that is tiered, making at least some level of health cover available to every UK business and giving employers an extra layer of flexibility.”

title: eat digestives chocolate bottom debate
story: Amna Saleem tweeted the question to her followers who swtly offered their two cents on the contentious argument.Amna wrote: I will get back to writing in a sec but help me settle something - when you eat a digestive chocolate biscuit you eat it with the chocolate face down, right  So you can enjoy maximum chocolate. Yes There was a mixture of outrage and jubilation on Twitter after many felt their biscuit eating beliefs had violated, while others were relieved to finally find someone who shared their technique.New techniques were offered, confusion was expressed and someone even threatened to call the biscuit police. Its safe to say its a heavily contested subject matter, especially to the biscuit fanatics.One tweeter named Margaret responded saying you might as well just chew on some hay, unless you have the chocolate on the bottom.Paul on the other hand had a more aggressive technique - to shove a whole one in my gob for maximum effect.Similarly, another tweeter suggested just having two, in a sandwich format, meaning more biscuit and less mess - so everyone wins.In response to Amna, @sjh_canada offers this bizarre explanation.Although it contradicts Amnas way of thinking, this tweeter has a well-thought-out theory behind their technique.Meanwhile this tweeter is taking things to another level threatening to call the police.Hes clearly not a fan of chocolate thumb prints all over his possessions.After all this debating, Anna seems to find an answer to her own question when she Googles the question and receives this answer.Margaret agrees with Amna as her technique provides the most most tasteMcVities have actually previously stated the chocolate actually goes on the bottom, confirming Amnas tweet.Someone wrote to the company on Facebook to ask the all-important question.Despite these answers, that wont stop social media users fighting over their biscuit opinions.And that definitely wasnt the end of this online debate as Amnas tweet was then shared on Reddit, with predictably hilarious results.Rawrbear writes: The packaging shows it chocolate side up. I feel that McVities caused this confusion themselves. Were not wrong or to blame, Big Biscuit Co. is!Its a true statement that McVities display the biscuit chocolate side up on the packaging, leading to much confusion.One Reddit user claims the biscuits are run through a lake of chocolate meaning its on the bottom.But another just replied that it sounds like something out of Charlie and the Chocolate Factory.While Welshy tries to explain the biscuits are made by dipping the bottoms in chocolate, -SaC lowers the tone of the conversation by saying Now I want to dip my bottom in chocolate.The debate then turns to branding as EverythingIsByDesign writes: The chocolate is on the bottom because the makers mark is on the top just like it is on a normal digestive.But RaymondHolt correctly states Pottery and antiquities often have the makers mark on the bottom.At which point -SaC lowers the tone yet again by saying: I’ve also seen more arse tattoos than I have face tattoos. I think we’re onto something here.However there is a sense of artistic licence coming into play when you eat your own biscuit.Witchfinder_Specic follows on from the point about logo branding by saying the fanciest side should be at the top.They write: On a plain digestive, the side with the name and logo pressed into is fancier than the flat side, so that is the top. But dip the flat side in chocolate and it becomes fancier than the non-chocolaty side, so the biscuit flips and the chocolate side now becomes the top.This Reddit user ends the debate with a parodied speech of physicist Brian Cox.He claims its all subjective as the universe has no up or down, among other scientic theories written in a Brian Cox voice.The Sun Online has approached McVities for comment - to end this debate once and for all.

title: nadine dorries brexit coup theresa may
story: Brexiteers trying to oust the PM have so far been frustrated by failing to cross the crucial threshold of  letters.But today a leading rebel insisted there are  backbenchers who have demanded a leadership vote.That means only two more are needed to trigger a challenge - suggesting a vote could come later this week.Nadine Dorries was one of the first MPs to announce in public that she wants the PM to go.Today she claimed backbench boss Sir Graham Brady has almost got enough letters for a vote of no confidence.She told the BBC: I think the numbers about . And I know of key people who are holding their letters back.Ms Dorries added that the number would have been reached alreadyit werent for cowardly men who are too scared to put a letter in.She said: I can tell you this... all the women have put their letters in.There are at least  MPs who say publicly or privately that they have put a letter in to Sir Graham.But he has revealed some rebels lie about putting in letters - meaning the true figure could even be less than that.This morning he again repeated that the key threshold of  has not yet been reached and said the vast majority of Tory MPs still support Mrs May eventhey plan to vote against her Brexit deal.Jacob Rees-Mogg, the Brexiteer ringleader, admitted that the attempted coup now looks a bit Dads Army.But he said that eventhere is no leadership challenge this week, there will be a fresh push to unseat the PM next month.

title: girl ovarian cyst pregnant fish philippines
story: Kimberly Robles Besinal, , from a remote island in Albay, the Philippines, began experiencing stomach pains last June.Her stomach started to swell and her family angrily accused her of having a secret lover.They forced Kimberly to undergo an ultrasound scan, which appeared to show a strange creature with fish-like eyes and a mouth in her belly.She says the pictures - combined with a traditional Filipino folklore and the youngsters love of swimming without underwear - led to the family to bizarrely accuse her of having sex with a fish.But after a year passed and no baby had materialised, doctors checked again.Kimberly is now trying to raise money for the operation to surgically remove the large cyst.I am having a hard time breathing and my chest feels tight. I feel like someone is choking me, she said.My family thought I was pregnant, but I had no boyfriend.They then believed I was pregnant by a mythical creature because I used to like swimming in the ocean without panties.Dr Massachusette Fernandez, the obstetrician-gynecologist who is treating Kimberly said: The scan really resembles a fish, but its not.She has an oian cyst. It is impossible to have a fish inside her oies.Kimberleys weight has also increased from  kilos to  kilos since last year, which medics have put down to the cyst.Her father, Pablo Robles, said the family now accept that Kimberly had never been pregnant - either from a local boy or a fish.At first, I told her to tell me the truthshe is pregnant. I was angry but now I believe her.Locals on the tiny island of Manaet in the Bacacay region believe that women should stay out of the ocean for up to five days after their monthly period.The strange belief comes from an ancient Filipino superstition which says that when a woman on her period swims in the sea without underwear, organisms can enter her vagina causing her to fall pregnant to a mythical creature.Despite the medical evidence, Kimberleys grandmother and cousin still believe the growth in her belly is that of a mythical fish from the local Gumaliw folklore, she says.Kimberleys cousin, Amada Robles, said Kimberley likes swimming in the sea near her house.Amada said: I always scold her for doing that especially on her menstruation day, but she is so hard-headed.

title: skeleton ancient egyptian woman unborn baby inside 3700 years
story: The woman, believed to have been about  years old, was due to give birth to the near-term baby, which was found in a head-down position, say researchers.Inside her tomb, uncovered near Aswan in southern Egypt, were beads made from ostrich egg shells, pottery and jars.The joint Italian-American archaeological mission found the burial place of the pregnant woman in her last months during work on the Kom Ombo archaeological project in Aswan, the Egyptian Ministry of Antiquities announced on Facebook.“Initial analysis of the womans womb revealed problems or imbalances in the pelvic area, which indicated that she was probably suffering from a fracture that was treated incorrectly and probably caused death,” it explained.Preliminary studies indicated the woman’s age at the time of her death was “about  years”.The mum-to-be “was in the months of her last pregnancy and about to give birth as the structure of the [foetus] is located in the pelvic area has already stabilised in the position of childbirth,” the ministry said.One of the researchers, Dr Zuhari, said the woman’s skeleton was found wrapped in “a flask of leather and next to it were pots of pottery, one was an Egyptian jar that was worn out due to frequent use, the other was a polished red and black container.Dr Zuhari said the container was one “ usually made by travellers who lived in this area, and was similar to Nubian pots”.The grave itself is in a cemetery used by travellers to bury their dead as they moved to Egypt through desert areas from the south, during -BC.The ministry said the tomb contained “unexpected offerings” such as beads of ostrich egg shell, “which is likely to have been made by the makers of beads.Her family has put a large amount of unused material to honour her memory”.Professor Sandra Wheeler, University of Central Florida, told National Geographic: “The discovery of a foetus still inside a woman from this period is extremely rare.“This reinforces the idea that childbirth was precarious and that maternal mortality was something people faced all the time.”Newsweek said that Kom Ombo, her burial place, was an agricultural town known for its ancient “double” temple, where two sets of rooms including courts and hallways were built in honour of two gods.

title: man sues spa x rated massage
story: The -year-old man claims a sex pest masseur began fondling his buttocks and caressing his todger, leaving him terried.   The victim said he “completely froze” and after he left the upscale Living Fresh Men’s Spa on West nd Street, Manhattan, he called the cops. According to his Manhattan Supreme Court lawsuit the man lay face down on a table, clad only in a towel, as masseur Pei Tian began “what appeared to be a normal massage.”But  minutes into the session, court papers say Tian started to focus “exclusively on the client’s buttocks for an inordinate amount of time, making him very uncomfortable”.As the customer became more and more uncomfortable with Tian’s focus on his buttocks, He then moved his fingers below the man’s buttocks and began caressing his privates, the suit says.The document added: “At no point had Arnau indicated, orally or otherwise, that he consented to Tian touching his penis. “Nor did he ever indicate any desire for him to do so.”The man was so shocked by Tian’s actions that “he completely froze” until the masseur “threw off his towel and told him to turn over”.The court papers said at that point, having shaken off his initial state of shock, he abruptly rose from the massage table and demanded that Tian leave the room.The rattled client immediately called cops, who arrived and arrested Tian.The worker was charged with forcible touching and sexual abuse, according to court papers, and his criminal case is still pending.The victim did nota message seeking comment, but a receptionist at Living Fresh Men’s Spa told The Post that the masseur still works for the company.The receptionist, who would provide only his first name, Sean, added that Tian had been with the spa for a decade. title: jacob rees mogg brexit coup theresa may dads army
story: As their attempt to boot out Theresa May flopped due to a shortage of no confidence letters, today MPs said they were set to move on her after the vote on her Brexit deal.The Brexiteer ERG ringleader Rees-Mogg, who put his own letter in last week, admitted that getting the total of  was showing to be quite dficult.When askedthe plot had gone a bit Dads Army he replied Ive always admired Captain Mainwaring.But he insisted that when it came to the letter total patience is a virtue, and reckoning time would come next month.And he stressed: Do  want to come with me or not  I may find that they dont or they dont do it today but when we get the meaningful vote.And fellow Rebel Steve Baker said: Its very hard to see those letters not beingshe loses the meaningful vote... I do think its now or never.Mr Rees-Mogg also argued that rebels had to move now - otherwise Mrs May might lead the Tories towards another catastrophic defeat.He said: I think it is now or the Prime Minister will lead the Conservatives into the next election.And getting the deal through on the back of Labour votes would split the party and the country, he added.Deep isions in the Brexiteer camp has harmed the coup - with anger that major figures including Priti Patel, Iain Duncan Smith and Sir Bernard Jenkin had not publicly backed the plot, even though they have trashed Mrs Mays deal already.The Sun revealed a bitter new row erupted as some accused others of trying to oust Mrs May because they want peerages.Senior Eurosceptics had warned that yesterday was the moment of truth for the PM as they urged more MPs to hand in their letters.Only  have gone public with them so far amid fears that toppling Mrs May could collapse the entire Government and let Jeremy Corbyn into power.Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt warned overnight that it would risk the most appalling chaos and could even stop us from getting through to the other side of Brexit.THERESA Mays new plan to scrap the contentious Irish backstop using technology would not be enough to win over Brexit rebels, David Davis declared today.The ex-Brexit Secretary said the alternative arrangements proposal to keep the border open was a material movement forward.But he added: It isnt by itself enough.Mr Davis said plans for regulatory alignment in the future framework would to tie British industry to the EUs rules forever.And securing a free trade agreement with the EU is much, much more important than a customs union.Asked about plans for alternative arrangements to avoid having to use the backstop altogether - revealed in today’s Sun - Mr Davis said: There’s also the question about regulatory compliance as well and that is very important to businesses.We are likely to be in the lead in things like articial intelligence, genetics and so on. We cannot be a world leader in those industriessomebody  writes the regulations for us.Similarly, it is not just a Northern Ireland border issue that determines when we get out of a customs union, it is also the question of the customs arrangements that the government has proposed.Many people think this is either impossible or would take five or ten years to put in place. That is also unacceptable.His sentiment was backed up by MP Michael Fabricant, who said today: I shall be voting against [the deal] in the Division Lobby. Pen and paper not required. A botched coup will merely strengthen the Remainers.It was revealed this morning that Mrs May will fly to Brussels for afternoon tea with Jean Claude Juncker tomorrow as she desperately tries to seal off her hated deal.Today the PM got a boost from Bank of England boss Mark Carney as he came out in favour of her Brexit plan.The Bank governor told MPs he welcomed the transition arrangements in the withdrawal agreement.And he warned the chance of a No Deal outcome is uncomfortably high, adding that it would cause an economic shock across the UK and EuropeMeanwhile, this morning Mrs May faced down unhappy Brexiteers in her Cabinet for the first time since they reluctantly signed off her agreement.The Prime Minister hosted the weekly meeting in No with her recently reshuffled top team, following a string of high profile resignations last week which almost toppled her.The meeting took much longer than planned, and was said to focus on the future trade deal with the EU Mrs May will now hope to seal.Last night the so-called Pizza Club Plotters, who were due to meet to try and force her hand, backed down amid splits.Andrea Leadsom reportedly told the PM during todays Cabinet: Prime Minister, I don’t even like pizza!Mr Gove is now said to want to draw up plans for a revised Brexit deal in the event that Mrs Mays agreement gets voted down in the Commons next month - but Mrs Leadsom was keen to keep up the pressure on the PM ahead of this weekends crunch summit.But Brexiteer John Redwood tried to put pressure on the unhappy Brexit cabinet ministers to quit, saying they would be better off resigning together than vote for the unacceptable agreement.Mrs Mays spokesman insisted senior ministers are now absolutely united on Brexit, adding: Everybody is backing the Prime Minister to get the best possible deal for the country.EU leaders will meet this weekend in Brussels to likely sign, seal and deliver Mrs Mays hard-won deal.If they agree on it, it will go to the Commons for a crunch vote in the coming weeks.But the pressure will be ramped up today after the DUP fired another warning shot to the PM last night by siding with Labour on a key Budget vote.As part of the deal with the Northern Irish party, they agreed to vote with the Conservatives on all finance matters - but last night they abstained on every vote and even sided with the Opposition on one.DUPs Sammy Wilson told Newsnight: You’ve got to keep your side of the bargain, otherwise we don’t feel obliged to keep ours.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Conservative backbencher Daniel Kawczynski has suggested Theresa Mays decision not to take part in debates before last years election contributed to the Tories losing their parliamentary majority."One of the things that damaged us at the last general election was our leader not participating in the debates," he told Sky News."I picked up a certain amount of negativity on that during the election campaign in my constituency of Shrewsbury."Its vital we establish now, rather than right ahead of the general election, the rules and parameters of these debates."Most people in this country expect the leaders of all political parties to be challenged in a very public and robust way in these debates. Not just one of them but a series of them."
