title: campaigner harry leslie smith recovering
story: NewsCampaigner Harry Leslie Smith recovering in hospital after fallHis son says the Barnsley-born miners son and tireless campaigner is suffering from low blood pressureShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV News "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCampaigner and writer Harry Leslie Smith is recovering in hospital after a fall, his son has said. Tweets posted to the -year-old’s official account by son John said his father had low blood pressure and “drts in and out of consciousness, but it breathing well with oxygen.” War hero Harry shot to fame with a moving speech to Labour Party conference in . He stole the show, moving delegates to tears during a debate on the NHS and social care. Hospitals, doctors and medicine were for the privileged few, because they were run by profit, he told the hall. My memories stretch back almost a hundred years, andI close my eyes, I can smell the poverty that oozes from the dusty tenement streets of my boyhood. The Barnsley-born miner’s son has since become a tireless campaigner against poverty, for the rights of refugees and workers and for keeping the NHS in public hands.  Mr Smith is understood to have fallen ill in Canada, where he was visiting his son. His son tweeted: I told Harry before he fell into a deep sleep about the concern rippling across Twitter for him and he said to me, tell them, I love each of them so much. Harry joined the RAF at , serving as a pilot in World War II, lived through the Great Depression and lost his sisted Marion to tuberculosis when she was just  years old because his family couldn’t afford a doctor. Last year, he celebrated winning a battle with pneumonia, telling the Mirror he would have died without the NHS.  He said: “I know were it not for the NHS my le would have ended a long time ago because I come from an endless ancestry of hard-working folk whose labour never paid enough to afford a pleasant le. “The working class only came to good fortune when a Labour government was elected in .”

title: esther mcveys bid relate benefit
story: NewsEsther McVeys bid to relate to benefit sanction victims backfires spectacularlyShe may be gone as Work and Pensions Secretary - but Esther McVeys legacy of thoroughly peeing off benefit claimants lives onShareByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video esther-mcvey-posts-video-first-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIts less than a week since she threw in the towel as Work and Pensions Secretary over Brexit. But Esther McVey has not been holding back on Twitter since she was liberated to speak her mind. The MP - who was accused of misleading Parliament over the welfare shake-up Universal Credit - has retweeted messages calling herself gutsy and dignied. At least one of her tweets, however, appears to have backfired. A critic pointed out Universal Credit claimants can be sanctioned for three years for giving up their job.  Wonder whether @EstherMcVey will see her MPs salary reduced for quitting  Paul Treloar asked. She replied: Hi Paul. In answer to your question. By resigning, my salary has been halved.  This is, of course, mostly true. Ms McVey has lost her pound, top-up for being a Cabinet minister, forcing her to scrape by on a pound, MPs wage. But its fair to say it went down like a cup of the proverbial.   Many Twitter users claimed the MP was trying to relate to the plight of people forced to food banks by Universal Credit. Edward Paxton told her: So your trying to relate to people who barely get pound a year who literally have to freeze or starve let alone the rest regardless of situation, when youre on what pound get an extra house and expenses paid for and probably get paid for all sorts of other things  Twitter user Tom Lines told her: The question was whether the large salary you get as an MP would be reduced. It wasn’t. Naturally, you lost your ministerial salary when you decided to stop being a minister. But that is not the point that @PaulieTandoori was making. Another user joked: Halved to poundk as an MP mate... hardly straight to ramen noodles is it. And Liverpool Lib Dem councillor Kay Davies told her: You should quit as an MP. You have brought unprecedented levels of misery to so many people. And you continue to mock them. How much do you claim for weekly groceries off the tax payer  The Mirror are demanding a halt to the expansion of Universal Credit and for a review to take place. We say there are three options:Redesign UC to be fit for purpose Axe it in favour of the old systemUC is unfixable Introduce a brand new systemSign our petition to stop the rollout of Universal Credit across Britain and to replace it with a fairer system by signing our petition.  Despite the criticism Ms McVey later doubled down, posting a video in which she said she had to move offices, before adding: Change is dficult and Im prepared for that... you cant live in fear. She said she brought pound.billion into her former department to help benefit claimants, adding: It needed that and I fought for that.

title: tories pull votes avoiding embarrassing
story: NewsTories pull votes avoiding embarrassing defeat as DUP go on strike over BrexitThe hardline Northern Irish party have withdrawn their votes for the second day runningShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsTheresa May, with DUP leader Arlene Foster "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Government accepted a string of amendments to the Budget last night, threatened with an embarrassing defeat at the hands of the DUP. The hardline Northern Irish party are effectively on strike, tearing up their voting deal with the Government and vowing to abstain on Budget votes for a second day running. It leaves Theresa May seven votes short of an effective majority in the House of Commons and vulnerable to defeatsonly a few Tory rebels abstain or side with the opposition. DUP sources tonight told the Mirror their Westminster MPs planned to continue abstaining in votes on the Finance Bill in protest over Mrs May’s Brexit deal. After the votes were pulled, a Labour MP told the Mirror it was extraordinary. They said: We all ran over to vote and were told they had caved...!! The hardline Northern Irish party had promised to vote with the Government on key legislation, in a pact worth pound billion after the PM lost her majority at last year’s election.   The party, led by Arlene Foster, are opposed to Mrs May’s draft Brexit deal, which they say creates a ‘border’ down the Irish Sea. The DUP’s deputy leader Nigel Dodds urged Mrs May to “work towards a better deal” for the good of the Union. He said: “The Government will require DUP support to deliver its domestic agenda. We will continue to use our influence for the good of everyone across the United Kingdom.” DUP MP Sammy Wilson said Mrs May’s government had “torn up” promises made over Brexit, and the party “had to do something to show our displeasure.” Mr Dodds said that the agreement with Conservatives committed theDUPto pursue the shared objectives of strengthening the Union and seeking a Brexit that benefits all parts of the UK.   While theDUPhad kept to our word on the agreement, the resignation of several Conservative ministers showed that Mrs Mays deal does not represent those shared objectives, he said. He added: The Government will requireDUPsupport to deliver its domestic agenda. We will continue to use our influence for the good of everyone across the United Kingdom. If the Government can look beyond a Withdrawal Agreement, which is uniting people from across the political spectrum against it, and instead work towards a better deal, then an outcome can be delivered that truly works to benefit all parts of the United Kingdom. Both Brexiteer Boris Johnson and Chancellor Philip Hammond are due to attend theDUPs conference at the weekend, according to Co Fermanagh newspaper the Impartial Reporter.

title: tory brexiteers branded dads army
story: NewsTory Brexiteers branded Dads Army as splits scupper bid to topple Theresa MayJacob Rees-Mogg admitted "Ive always admired Captain Mainwaring" after his botched Tory coup was compared to the wartime favouriteShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsJacob Rees-Mogg as Captain Mainwaring and Steve Baker as... oh never mind"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTory Brexiteers today admitted their bid to topple Theresa May embarrassingly flopped because of infighting in their ranks. Tory MP Steve Baker said there is “a tactical disagreement” among supporters of the hardline European Research Groupof Tory Brexiteers, over when to force a no-confidence vote in Mrs May’s leadership. Jacob Rees-Mogg, who chairs the group, called on supporters to submit letters to Tory backbench chief Sir Graham Brady on Thursday. But they have so far failed to muster the  letters needed to trigger a vote. Mr Baker, a senior figure in the ERG, said today the group was split over whether to trigger the vote now or after Mrs May loses the Commons ‘meaningful vote’ on her Brexit deal.  He said the holdouts “want to defeat the Prime Minister, and they think they’re more likely to defeat the PM after she’s lost the meaningful vote. “That’s what’s holding back quite a material number of colleagues.” “But the letters are slowly going in,” he added. “I received a call last night to say that a letter had gone in. “So obviously it’s not the case that Jacob and I’s word is not enough to sht the Conservative Party, I would have been surprisedit had been. “But everybody faces grave choices.”  Asked why the letters had not materialised at the same event, a press conference by ERG-linked group Global Britain, Mr Rees-Mogg said: Patience is a virtue, virtue is a grace. We will see what letters come in due time. He added: Do  want to come with me or not  I may find that they dont or they dont do it today but when we get the meaningful vote. Thats a decision for them. Mr Rees-Mogg denied he was trying to mount a coup against Mrs May, insisting he was using the legitimate processes of party democracy. Theresa May has a Brexit deal, but the danger is looming that it will be defeated in the House of Commons. Even getting it past her Cabinet forced Esther McVey and Dominic Raab to resign. Now she faces two more hurdles - an EU summit with  leaders on November , and then the vote in Parliament at some point before Christmas. MPs are grouped in several factions - their warring opinions are explained more fully here. But or more vote against the deal, they will defeat the deal. Against the deal TORY BREXITEERS: There are up to  , led by Boris Johnson and Jacob Rees-Mogg. They will vote down a deal that keeps Britain trapped in vassalage with Brussels. TORY HARD REMAINERS: Only about a dozen, but many - including Justine Greening and Jo Johnson - will vote against, instead wanting a second referendum. DUP: Theresa Mays Northern Irish allies - who she handed pound.bn - are -strong. They will vote down the dealit allows customs checks between Ulster and Britain. LABOUR LOYALISTS: About  MPs are consistently loyal to Jeremy Corbyn on Brexit. The party has confirmed theyll be told to vote against the deal because it doesnt meet Labours six tests. LABOUR REMAINERS: There are about  hard Remainer Labour MPs. Theyre likely to oppose the deal to avoid enabling a Brexit.OTHERS: The SNP , Lib Dems , Plaid Cymruand Greensare all likely to vote against. For the deal TORY LOYALISTS: Well over  are likely to vote with Theresa May, for the deal. Many have paid government jobs - so would have to quitthey oppose her. NERVOUS LABOUR: Some Labour MPs could BACK a deal - fearing otherwise Britain will be plunged into an even worse No Deal. There could be  or more. Caroline Flint is among them. UnknownLABOUR BREXITEERS: There are only about half a dozen. It was generally thought theyd side with Theresa May, but Kate Hoey MP broke ranks and said she could vote against. Askedhis attempt to unseat the PM had been exposed as a Dads Army operation, Mr Rees-Mogg replied: Ive always admired Captain Mainwaring. Mr Baker added: “Two things have happened. Colleagues have consulted their associations, I don’t know what those conversations have yielded. “But also there’s been an enormous whipping operation over the weekend, including senior members of the voluntary party talking to members of parliament about what they’re doing, so I don’t know how opinion will have changed. Theresa Mays Cabinet has signed off a -page draft Brexit deal with Brussels - and it has enraged Tories. Here are some of the reasons why:The transition period can be extended - and we dont know how long for Goods face being checked between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK We need the EUs permission to quit the backstop European courts will still have a big hold on the UKFOR THE FULL GUIDE CLICK HERE “I do know what people told me they would do, and that hasn’t happened yet. “But it’s a very, very serious decision at this late stage to say you have no confidence in the Prime Minister. It’s a very high bar for people to get over and they’ve got to make their own decision. “ But he insisted that it was “inconcievable” that the  letters would not arrivethe Prime Minister lost the meaningful vote.  David Davis, also appearing at the press conference, introduced himself as the “former, former Brexit Secretary.” He refused to answer questions during the QA on whether he had himself submitted a letter to Sir Graham Brady. And his attempt to dodge questions on the subject at the end of the event were briefly hampered when he was unable to remember which pillar in the venue he’d left his bag next to. After a frantic search, he eventually found his belongings, but told the Mirror: “Now I’ve found the bag…I’m going.”

title: blind woman distraught after being
story: NewsBlind woman distraught after being turned away from cafe because of guide dogLauren Monument, , says staff at the Weston Beach Cafe, in Weston-super-Mare, made her feel degraded and embarrassed - but owners called it a misunderstandingShareCommentsByKaisha Langton:,  NOV NewsShe suffers with a rare genetic disorder meaning she has been blind since the age of  "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA blind woman claims she was refused entry to a cafe because of her guide dog. Lauren Monument, , and her husband, David, visited Weston-super-Mare with their two nephews on November  where they agreed to meet the rest of their family for lunch. The group tried to access Weston Beach Cafe but were turned away at the door for hygiene reasons and instead were told to sit outside in the cold, Lauren claims. She posted on Facebook: Would definitely not recommend the Weston Beach Cafe. Attempted to go in with my husband and our nephews today and was denied access due to having a Guide Dog. I tried to explain my rights as a Guide Dog owner and after having to justy why I have a Guide Dog the woman said I was not welcome in the cafe and would have to sit outside in the cold. We tried to explain the law to them by using my official Guide Dog access denial book but none of the staff in the cafe would read it or listen to the law. They sheepishly hid behind the counter and in the kitchen and walked away to avoid all conversation. They accepted my dog was a Guide Dog and refused entry regardless.  Lauren says she was instead told that they were not allowed to sit inside due to hygiene concerns. She suffers with a rare genetic disorder meaning she has been blind since the age of . She was given her guide dog Goldie five years ago and she is now her constant companion. She said: Access was refused on the basis it was unhygienic due to the carvery, this was despite the fact there was sufficient space at the opposite side of the cafe. My eight-year-old nephew even chose to speak up and wanted to call the police saying it wasnt fair. I will be taking all the appropriate legal action required and also want to urge you to think twice about whether this is a place you want to spend your money at. Please support me and other Guide Dog owners by avoiding this place at all costs. I left feeling degraded and embarrassed. Avoid, avoid, avoid.  The cafe had a notice in the window advising that small well behaved dogs were permitted entry from Monday to Saturday but on Sundays were not allowed due to hygiene reasons. The notice said: Small well behaved dogs allowed from Monday to Saturday. Unfortunately, we cannot allow dogs on Sundays for hygiene reasons as the Carvery is served in the main seating area. Please note, dogs must be kept on the floor and not be able to reach the tables where good is served. All dogs welcome on outside on the terrace area. Laurens Facebook post has been shared over  times by other concerned iniduals.  Weston Beach Cafe posted a statement on Facebook: It is with much regret that I must make this statement concerning a person being refused entry to our cafe with a guide dog. I have spoken to the waitress that refused the customer entry and she is adamant that at no time did the dog owner identy her dog as being a guide dog. I myself asked why she felt that it was discriminatory to refuse a dog entry, at which point she identied that she is blind and her dog is a guide dog. I immediately offered the group an inside table to which she replied, I dont want to now. It is very unfortunate that the lady feels she was discriminated against. We have ALWAYS allowed guide dogs inside the cafe, even during peak season. Im currently having the CCTV footage reviewed and a copy will be made available to any parties concerned to resolve this misunderstanding. It is understandable that the lady was very upset to be refused entry due to our dog policy, but I feel this could have been avoided had she identied her dog as being a guide dog upon entering. A spokesperson for Guide Dogs said: It is always distressing for a guide dog owner to be refused the access they are entitled to by law and we are saddened to hear about this incident.

title: christmas traditions like pudding pennies
story: NewsChristmas traditions like pudding pennies, carol singing and trees are dying outChristmas used to be a time for tipping the paperboy or binman, supping on eggnogg and watching a James Bond film - but fewer people are joining in than everShareCommentsByGrant Bailey:,  NOV NewsA third of people wont put up a Christmas tree "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMuch-loved Christmas traditions such as eggnog, pennies in the pudding and carol singing are now practically a thing of past, it has emerged. Tipping the paperboy and binmen and even watching a James Bond film on December th are no longer part of the festive routine. Researchers who carried out a detailed study found time and financial pressures are to blame along with a fear of not wanting to give the impression of being old fashioned. Overall more than half the , adults who took part expressed a belief that old traditions are falling by the wayside.  The stats show just a third of Brits will hang a wreath on their door this year, and only  per cent will put up a Christmas tree. Amazingly, one in four will NOT enjoy a Christmas dinner with all the trimmings this year. In fact, only seven in  are planning a traditional giving and receiving of gts. British Corner Shop – who export products to Brits around the world – carried out the in-depth research. A spokeswoman said: “Our research found there are lots of classic traditions that appear to be falling by the wayside.  “In fact, what we consider to be ‘traditional’ Christmas customs may no longer have a place at the Christmas of the future. “However, where old traditions die off, new ones are coming up to take their place – and there are still lots of old traditions that are as popular as ever.” It also emerged one tenth of festive Brits are set to watch a James Bond film on television – often a staple part of a long Christmas afternoon slumped in front of the TV. And just one in seven plan to have a nativity scene taking pride of place in their front room. Fewer than one in  plan to do Christmas carolling this season, and only five per cent will take part in Christingle. Nearly eight in  adults think that people have fewer interactions with friends and neighbours as a result of traditional Christmas activities decline.  And the majority of Brits believe that as years go by, Christmas gets less special, with the Christmas spirit peaking at age , then petering out. Of more modern traditions that have come to prominence in recent years, a fth of Brits now take part in a ‘Secret Santa’. And three in  love wearing novelty Christmas jumpers, with a further one in five visiting German Christmas markets in the run-up to the big day. A huge  per cent of respondents believe Christmas seems to start earlier and earlier every year, with eight in  Brits wishing it would revert to its old values. The study also uncovered the key dferences in how younger and older Brits will choose to celebrate Christmas this year. While the Christmas dinner remains the focal point for the day, and the festive event Brits cannot do without regardless of age, there were some key dferences.  Brits aged  to  are more likely to prioritise putting up a Christmas tree to mark the occasion. They are also more inclined to watch a Christmas film, open an advent calendar in the run up to the big day and listen to Christmas songs, according to the OnePoll study. Brits over the age of  prefer to celebrate by eating mince pies, hanging a wreath on their door and going for a post-dinner walk to burn off some calories. British Corner Shop’s spokeswoman added: “Young or old, some things are so quintessentially Christmas we couldn’t be without them. “While the entirety of the Christmas season is made up of a patchwork of traditions, nothing is more vital to the experience than friends and family gathering around the table for the most indulgent supper of the year.” Christmas traditions on the wane - and percentage of nation who WILL adopt them this year- Send a letter to Father Christmas through the fire - %- Christingle - %- Drink eggnog - %- Put a sixpence or penny in a Christmas pudding - %- Going out to sing Christmas Carols - %- Decorate a gingerbread house - %- Donate a shoebox to charity- %- Watch a James Bond film - %- Set fire to the Christmas pudding - %- Go to the Christmas pantomime - %- Hang mistletoe - %- Give a tip to your postman or binman - %- Have a nativity scene - %- Put holly and ivy up - %- Leave a mince pie and carrots out for Santa and his reindeer - %- Have a real Christmas tree - %- Drink mulled wine - %- Watch The Queens Speech - %- Put a stocking out - %- Go for a post-Christmas dinner walk - %

title: dad would lie foetal position
story: NewsDad would lie in foetal position shaking after we and sons died in house fireJohn Bickley, , said said he fell into a "deep black hole" after losing his family in a blaze at their home Anglesey, North WalesShareCommentsBySteve RobsonAbigail OLeary:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsJohn and Heather Bickley on their wedding day in St Lucia "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA father has described the agony of living without his we and two young sons who died in a horric house fire. John Bickley said he would curl up in the foetal position shaking after losing we Heather, , and sons Felix, , and Oscar, six, in the blaze at their home Anglesey, North Wales. The grieving father, now , said he fell into a deep black hole as he tried to cope with unimaginable grief after the tragedy in . A fire investigation determined the blaze was caused by a freezer motor overheating in the utility room, reports the Manchester Evening News. It is believed Mrs Bickley, who worked as a staff nurse at North Manchester Hospital before becoming a detective in North Wales Police, and her children were overcome by smoke as they tried to flee. An inquest heard how Mr Bickley, , was out at work at the time and came back to find fire crews battling the blaze in vain.  A coroner later ruled all three were accidental deaths - adding that the house did not have a working smoke alarm fitted that may have saved their lives. John, a cabinetmaker originally from Prestwich, has told how he struggled to cope with the deep black hole of grief he found himself in. Writing for the Manchester Evening News, John has opened up about how he coped with the pain after managing to find love again. Wed laugh so much it hurt Heather spent her whole le in public service, first at North Manchester Hospital as a Staff Nurse following which she was a serving police officer in the North Wales Police for  years. She was uncomplicated, principled and loving, creating a wonderful family home for us all. My we was truly the rock and driving force behind our family. She adored Christmas which would start the day after her birthday on the November  and wouldnt end until I urged her to take down the decorations as we approached the end of January. This week she would have been just fty-four. As another Christmas approaches her presence is very strong - I can see her crazily filling our home with tinsel and lights and so much love, having the time of her le.  Felix was very sporty. He loved swimming, karate, playing football and dreamed of playing for Liverpool. I have wonderful memories of spending time together sitting at a mountain top cafe drinking his favourite hot chocolate, on a rest from skiing. Believing he’d actually flown a space ship to Mars after a ride in Disney World and sitting on my shoulders as we danced at a Florence and The Machine concert, just a few weeks before he died. He was so competitive and couldn’t bear losing to his younger brother. He had a maturity beyond his years and was such wonderful company when you had him to yourself. We’d talk for hours together. Oscar at , was still a little boy, who’d not yet lived any sort of le. He was such a sweet natured boy, very happy to sit and play lego for hours, always wanting to please, and he never complained about anything. He used to call Felix ‘seesaw’ before he could pronounce his name properly and adored his older brother, always trying to copy him. During the last six months of his le we bought a large trampoline which he absolutely loved to jump around on. Every night he’d want me to jump on it with him too. He was so studious and clever.  One of the best memories I have of my sons is when we would go on any journey and they would sit together at the front of my van. They just loved sitting high up as we all sang together at the top of our voices to lots of dferent music. We’d laugh so much it hurt. At night I would curl up in the foetal position, violently shaking My emotional state after the fire was severely shut down with the trauma. I couldn’t cope with any contact with anyone other than close friends and family, for fear of breaking down. I was incapable of personal interaction. I felt like I was in a deep black hole with no emotional strength to get out of it. I would run daily in an effort to keep moving and to exhaust myself in the hope I would sleep at night and be able to remove myself from the reality of my le. I had to keep moving because to sit still would risk being smothered by their deaths. I could barely breath sometimes. At night time I would curl up in the foetal position violently shaking as the reality of my le descended. We take for granted how precious le is  The inquest was brutal. The Coroner made clear that had smoke alarms been in situ my family may have survived. The seat of the fire was established to be an electrical fault in a fridge which had been left by the previous owners of the house. We always think it won’t happen to us. We take for granted how precious le is and somehow mistakenly believe that tragedies are suffered by others. But one minute my beautul family were larger than le, full of so much energy, noise, fun, laughter and love and the next they were piles of dust in three plastic brown urns in my living room. The silence was deafening and the pain indescribable. I urge every reader to take the time to ensure you have a smoke alarm installed in your home and to test those already in situ. Most fire services offer free home checks and many provide free smoke alarmsneeded. Its a matter of minutes to make you and your family safe. Smoke alarms save lives. A relationship with Jill or anyone  was a million miles from my mind  I had support from so many family, friends, the community of Benllech and Heather’s colleagues in the police. Jill was someone who wasn’t afraid to ask probing questions and listen to uncomfortable answers. She was a distant friend who didn’t know my family, so it was easier to talk to her than people close to me who grief-stricken themselves and coming to terms with what had happened. We were very good friends at school and for a few years after, so it felt comfy being in her company. I could just be myself. A relationship with Jill or anyone  was a million miles from my mind. The relationship was a gradual process which felt very uncomfortable at first with mixed emotions and a lot of guilt. I had been with Heather for twenty-three very happy years and so it felt very strange to be with someone . Jill and I regularly spoke about these feelings. All of le felt strange, not just a new relationship. It’s like existing in some parallel universe – my we and sons in one and a strange new world in another. Each day I have to bridge the gap between the two to try and make sense of my le.  Jill and I have always taken one day at a time and continue to do so. She reminds me daily that I am free to leave. Not because she doesn’t love me but because she does. She tells me love has to be free – which I didn’t understand at first – but eight years later I do - and it is in this space that we are able to walk together. Dont hide away from the world Even in the darkest of places light can get through, but only with time and with the right help. At first I didn’t want counselling but over time realised I couldn’t manage my grief alone. It was an outlet where I could talk and cry without judgement. Don’t hide away from the world and take the goodness that people offer you. It made such a dference to my le being surrounded by so many people who cared. The gt of their kindness and compassion was something I’ll never forget.

title: inside queen prince philips romance
story: NewsInside Queen and Prince Philips romance on their th wedding anniversaryWhat you might not know about the Queen and Prince Philip - we look at their nicknames to sleeping arrangements on their wedding anniversaryShareCommentsByJo-Anne RowneyAudience Growth Editor:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsPrincess Elizabeth and Lt Philip Mountbatten after their wedding  "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Queen and Prince Philip are celebrating their st wedding anniversary today, but how much do we actually know about their romance  The couple’s royal romance spans decades, but its been fairly private. The reality is the romance started early on - when Elizabeth was eight, and ended in a devoted marriage. As they mark their wedding anniversary we look at the Queen, , and Prince Philip’s, , le together. From their nicknames for each other to settling into royal le and living arrangements. What they think makes their relationship successful He is someone who doesnt take easily to compliments. But he has, quite simply, been my strength and stay all these years, and I and his whole family, in this and many other countries, owe him a debt greater than he would ever claim or we shall ever know, the Queen has said previously. While Prince Philip has said it’s about having “dferent interests” and “tolerance”.  How did they meet  The Queen and Prince Philip first met in  at Elizabeth’s uncle’s wedding to Princess Marina of Greece and Denmark. She was eight, and he was  - apparently it was love at first sight. Move forward three years and they crossed paths again at the Royal Naval College in Devon. King George VIs official biographer, Sir John Wheeler-Bennett wrote: “This was the man with whom Princess Elizabeth had been in love from their first meeting.” Prince Philip jumped over the tennis nets as she watched on. Marion Crawford, Elizabeths governess, recalled: I thought he showed off a good deal. She added: She never took her eyes off him the whole time.” While Philip liked Elizabeth it seems marriage was not on his mind yet. Well, wed met at Dartmouth, and as far as I was concerned it was a very amusing experience, going on board the yacht and meeting them, and that sort of thing, and that was that, he told biographer Basil Boothroyd. This time they decided to keep in touch and write to each other while Prince Philip headed off to serve in the military. Philip was also invited to spend Christmas in  with the Royal Family at Windsor.  Long distance relationships In  some of their letters were auctioned off. Elizabeth shared her woes over a long distance relationship. I was  years of age and he was  and a cadet just due to leave. He joined the Navy at the outbreak of war, and I only saw him very occasionally when he was on leave — I suppose about twice in three years. Then when his uncle and aunt, Lord and Lady Mountbatten, were away he spent ious weekends away with us at Windsor. Then he went to the Pacic and Far East for two years. Whatever happened to a good old love letter ey  How they kept their relationship on the down low While Philip was away at sea, Elizabeth kept a picture of him in her room. She realised later the clean shaven Philip was a bit too obvious to recognise. She switched out her photo of him with one of him sporting a big old beard, which was far less recognisable. That’s one way to stop the gossip. They’re cousins The Queen and Philip are actually cousins! Second cousins once removed through King Christian IX of Denmark - they’re also third cousins through great-great-grandmother Queen Victoria. Keeping up here  Queen and Prince Philip in photos as royal couple celebrate st wedding anniversary The engagement ring Elizabeth’s and Philip’s engagement was announced on July   They posed together arm in arm at the Palace to mark the occasion the very next day. Philip actually designed her engagement ring - which was platinum and diamond. It was made by the jewellers Philip Antrobus Ltd using diamonds from a tiara belonging to his mother Princess Alice of Greece. His grand gesture on their wedding day Prince Philip made a big change for the Queen. Knowing she disliked smoking he gave up the cigarettes. He actually went cold turkey the day of his wedding, the brave man. What’s in a name   If you watched The Crown on Netflix you’ll know there was a bit of a kerfuffle regarding titles. Prince Philip struggled with the new dynamic between them - essentially he was the supporting act. Philip let his title Prince Philip of Greece and Denmark go and became Lieutenant Philip Mountbatten. He applied for British nationality and in February  he became a naturalised British subject. He also converted from Greek Orthodox to Anglican. Just five months later in July  their engagement was announced. When they married in November that year, he was given the title Duke of Edinburgh. And for a very brief time in  to  - before taking on the throne- The Queen took on the title Princess Elizabeth, Duchess of Edinburgh in a bid to calm things down.  Nicknames It’s not all titles though, the royal couple have nicknames for each other too. Prince Philip has a few for the Queen. Cabbage, Darling and Lilibet are a few of the names he calls her. Peter Morgan, who made The Queen tv series, says he has it “on good authority” that Cabbage is the prefered term… I inquired in royal circles and was told on very good authority that that is what the Duke sometimes calls the Queen, he said. If you’re wondering where it comes from, it derives from the French “mon petit chou”, which is ‘my darling’ - translating to my little cabbage in English. Sweet gestures  Prince Philip apparently always made sure dinner was ready for The Queen when she was working hard. He is reportedly a very good cook, according to author Ingrid Seward. In My Husband and I: The Inside Story Of  Years Of Royal Marriage she says he cooked dinner for the children too while she was off on duty. When The Queen was home he liked to cook her breakfast and he’s said to whip up a mean omelette, scrambled eggs and smoked haddock. Honeymoon The pair honeymooned on the Mountbatten Estate Broadlands in Hampshire. They wrote to their families sharing their joy at being married. It’s all rather sweet. I only hope that I can bring up my children in the happy atmosphere of love and fairness which Margaret and I have grown up in. We behave as though we had belonged to each other for years! Philip is an angel—he is so kind and thoughtful, Elizabeth told her parents. Prince Philip wrote to his aunt: Cherish Lilibet  I wonderthat word is enough to express what is in me. Shes the only thing in this world which is absolutely real to me and my ambition is to weld the two of us into a new combined existence that will not only be able to withstand the shocks directed at us but will also have a positive existence for the good. How sweet are these two   The royals are a dferent breed it seems and are all for dferent beds. Etiquette expert Lady Pam and Her Majestys cousin explained in a biography about the Queen: In England, the upper class always have had separate bedrooms. You dont want to be bothered with snoring or someone flinging a leg around. Then when you are feeling cosy you share your room sometimes. It is lovely to be able to choose. story: NewsNorth Koreans infested with parasitic worms because human faeces used on farmsWARNING - GRAPHIC CONTENT: A soldier who was shot and wounded as he defected to South Korea claims most people in the North "probably" have parasitesShareCommentsByChris kitching:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video first-footage-north-korean-defector-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA North Korean soldier who was shot five times as he defected claims most people in the secretive country have parasitic worms because human faeces is used as fertiliser. Oh Chong Song was wounded by his comrades in a hail of bullets as he dashed across the demilitarised zone into the South in a dramatic moment caught on CCTV. The -year-old was rescued and airlted to hospital, where South Korean doctors who examined him found that he had in long parasites in his intestine. In his first interview, Mr Oh claims his generation has no loyalty to Kim Jong-un, and most people in the North probably have parasites inside their bodies.  Mr Oh told Japans Sankei Shimbun newspaper: We use human excrement as fertiliser in the North and most people probably have parasites. Parasites dont grow in malnourished people. They found them inside me because I was well nourished. WARNING: GRAPHIC CONTENT  Mr Ohs le was saved by South Korean doctors after he was nearly killed fleeing the Kim regime. Medics said his body was like a broken jar and he was on deaths doorstep. According to the Korea Biomedical Review, species of roundworms were found inside the soldiers body.  Sankei Shimbun said Japanese intelligence officials confirmed Mr Ohs identitity before it published the interview this week. Mr Oh, the son of a major-general, said he doesnt resent his former comrades who shot him as he fled across the border at the Panmunjom truce village in November last year. He said: If they didnt shoot they would face heavy punishment. SoI was them, I would have done the same. He claims about  per cent of his generation have no loyalty to North Koreas current leader and he has no allegiance to his homeland despite his privileged birth and upper class upbringing.  Most people have little interest in the countrys politics, he added. Mr Oh said: Probably about  per cent of my generation has no interest or loyalty. If the regime was able to feed the people we would applaud that, but they are giving us nothing. Mr Oh denied South Korean media reports that he was fleeing because he was wanted for murder in the North. He told the newspaper that he got into trouble and started drinking, but on his way back to his post he broke through a checkpoint. He then decided to defect because he feared he would be executed.

The scene was recorded by an onlooker in the Jorge Teixeira neighbourhood of Manaus, Amazonas, Brazil. Sabrina Leite, , had been in front of her house when two men on a motorbike approached her. She says one of the men, later identied as Magdeel da Silva, , demanded her mobile phone. Sabrina said: I could feel they didnt have any [weapons], they just arrived saying pass the phone. I saw they didnt have anything and thats why I reacted. If they had been armed I would never have reacted.  Quick-thinking Sabrina threw her phone into the house and took off after the suspect when he tried to run away. Sabrina says her neighbour was passing in his car and stopped to assist her. He was running away, she said. My neighbour went after him in the car and reached him. Then I ran and immobilised him with a sleeper hold, I lay on the ground and put him in an arm lock. In the video, Sabrina can be seen lying on the ground on top of a da Silva whose armed is trapped in a lock between her legs. She then twists the lock tighter, sending the suspected thief into screams of pain as onlookers look on.  Sabrina told local news outlet G she learnt the arm lock through practising jiu-jitsu. She says she spent  minutes on the ground with the suspect until the police arrived. The suspect was arrested and will respond in court for attempted robbery. title: fans backing can be points in the bag for dundee united
story: There are few managers operating in the Championship right now who know better than Robbie Neilson just how powerful fans can be.As a player, he played more than two thirds of his  plus games for Hearts, whose supporters, arguably, create the best atmosphere of any club outside of the Old Firm when their team is playing in front of them at Tynecastle.And Robbie, of course, experienced more of what the Jambos fans have to offer when he successfully managed them for two-and-a-half years.Those spells in Edinburgh, in particular, taught him the backing of a passionate support can be worth points to a team.And he believes that can prove the case now he’s in charge at Dundee United.Since taking over from Csaba Laszlo at Tannadice last month, Robbie has mentioned the quality of the backing Arabs have given his rejuvenated team on several occasions.And he firmly believes they’ve more than played their part in an impressive unbeaten run of four wins and a draw that has seen the Tangerines re-emerge as serious promotion contenders from the second tier.On Tuesday night, however, it could be a case of ided loyalties for some Arabs, simply because United will be facing Alloa in a re-arranged league outing at the same time as Scotland face what could be a vital Nations League clash with Israel at Hampden.Having been blown away by the backing so far, the manager suspects it will be a case of club before country for most.“I’m definitely looking for a big turnout,” he said.“If there are any more pull-outs, my problem could be a few players might get called up for the Scotland squad!”Jokes aside, he does believe most Arabs will be in their usual seats at Tannadice and providing the kind of backing that’s become the envy of the rest of the second tier.“You have that Scotland game but the fans have been brilliant since I came in,” he said.“We took nearly , fans up to Ross County last weekend and we took , to Dunfermline the other week as well.“We’ve had great backing at home as well and, hopefully, they will turn up in numbers.“I understand midweek football means it’s always dficult for fans to make the journey.“We hope we can prove to them thatthey come along we’ll try to entertain and try to get a result.”As good as the backing so far has been, the manager does stress it remains down to his team to always make sure the supporters in the stands are given something to shout about.“The fans can make a massive dference but the initial stage will come from the players because the players, in the first  minutes of the game, have to set the tone,” he said.“They have to set the intensity and they have to get the fans off their seats.“If we can do that it reciprocates from the fans and we start putting pressure on teams and that’s what we need.”And that experience of playing with Hearts tells himthe support is on top form, at times it can mean points are picked up before a ball is even kicked.“I’ve played in venues where teams have come and you knew, because of the atmosphere and intensity, the game was done in the warm-up,” he said.“You knew you were going to win the game because the opposition couldn’t handle the atmosphere.“We need the supporters to try to give us that and we know they can.”

title: revealed arsenal watched dundee prospect kerr waddell
story: Dundee kid Kerr Waddell was watched by English Premier League giants Arsenal during the summer.And the -year-old’s progress continues to be monitored by a string of clubs from south of the border.Wednesday saw Waddell extend his loan at Championship outfit Morton until the end of the season, a move that will free him up to play in the Scottish Cup as well as league matches.Waddell made training programme.The loan was delayed, however, and he played in the Dark Blues opening build up game at Brechin City at the end of June, when he was watched by Gunners scouts.That was with a view to adding him to their U  squad and although the spying mission did not lead to an offer being tabled, Arsenal and others down south have been keeping tabs on his progress at Morton.New Dundee boss Jim McIntyre has also had reports on him but with good options available in defence, he’s decided the player’s development will be best served by remaining at Morton until the end of the season.Waddell broke into the first team at Dens early last season and got the goals that earned a vital win over Hearts a year past September.Injury and the arrival of experienced central defensive pair Genseric Kusunga and Steven Caulker in the early weeks of this year, saw his appearances in the second half of the campaign dry up.At Morton he’s made  appearances so far this term.The Dens gaffer has said he’s keeping an eye on all his players out on loan to see what they might add to the first-team should they be recalled in January.He said: “We send people to go and watch them so we are getting proper feedback.“Ideally, going forward I would like a position created for the loan players, somebody who keeps an eye on them so we are getting reports on each game.“The possibility is there for bringing them back but they need to be doing well where they are.”n Glen Kamara played  minutes for Finland last night in their - Nations League loss in Greece.

title: win against alloa could see dundee united eat into ayrs lead
story: Dundee United go into today’s re-arranged Championship clash with Alloa knowing they can eat into the gap at the top of the table.The weekend saw leaders Ayr United slip up when they were held at home by Morton.It means three points for the Tangerines today will mean a deficit that stood at eight when gaffer Robbie Neilson took over last month would be down to just three.And it would leave them able to wipe out the Honest Men’s advantage when the pair meet at Tannadice next week, though they could still trail Ross County, who currently lie second.Robbie has stressed he and his players will be looking no further forward than today’s outing but already the meeting with Ayr on Friday week is shaping up to be one of the most important games of the season so far.United remain hopeful of having skipper Fraser Fyvie, centre-half Frederic Frans and full-back Callum Booth available for today.They were all stepping up their work in training over the weekend after injury problems.If they’ve suffered no reactions, they’ll be in the squad.And in the case of Frans and Booth, both of whom have missed games, the manager has admitted that would give him a nice selection headache.“They have been doing well in the team but so have the players who’ve taken over from them while they were injured,” said Robbie.The reserves are not in action this week and don’t have another competitive fixture until they’re due to face Celtic in a league game early next month. story: THE countdown to Christmas in Inverness will begin officially on Sunday evening when thousands are expected to take part in the switch-on of the Christmas lights in the city centre.It will begin with a traditional torchlit procession led by Santa and Inverness Provost Helen Carmichael and escorted by mascots including Woody and Buzz Lightyear from Toy Story who will be making their first visit to the event.Families are asked to make their way to Crown Primary School from pm to buy their torches and take their places behind members of the City of Inverness Senior and Youth Pipe Bands who will be competing amongst themselves to see who can be the most outrageously decorated.The procession will set off from the school at .pm and will travel down Stephens Brae to High Street.After arriving there, the children will be invited to help Santa turn on the Christmas lights with a series of boisterous countdowns led by host Nicola McAlley of STV.After each section has twinkled into le, members of the procession will gather outside Inverness Town House where they will get their first glimpse of the colourful lighting scheme which was recently installed during the buildingrsquos refurbishment.After the Christmas and Town House lights have been switched on, Santa and the provost will join families for the traditional Christmas carol service Ding Dong Merrily Old High.It will start at .pm in the Old High Church.Councillor Bet McAllister is a member of the Inverness Events and Festivals Working Group.ldquoThe Christmas lights torchlight procession is one of the most popular events in our Winter Festival programme for the younger members of our community and we are looking forward to creating something really magical for them to enjoy, she said.Tuesday  Nov  : PM

title: Dress donations help with baby loss
story: A CHARITY which transforms wedding dresses and occasion dresses into handmade garments for stillborn babies is seeking volunteers in Inverness.Zaagi aims to support grieving families facing the stress and the heartache of bereavement following the loss of a baby to miscarriage, stillbirth or neo-natal death.It was founded three years ago by bereaved Lauder mother Kim Shaw-Walker. title: Former city shop gets a new lease of life
story: DOWNSIZING could be the way to breathe new le into Inverness city centrersquos empty retail units.That is the hope of local businessman Salim Ladha, who has opted to convert the former Cleorsquos gt shop on Lombard Street into the six unit Studioz .Mr Ladha believes that by subiding the unit, it will be more affordable and sustainable for small businesses, and end the cycle of opening and closure which has affected the premises in the recent past.ldquoBecause footfall is lower than it used to be, itrsquos dficult for retail businesses to make it work, he said.ldquoWe were renting out this unit, but it was just closing every two years, so I thought thatI turned it into small units, I would have at least two or three occupied all the time.One tenant is already lined up to take on one of the units next month and Mr Ladha hopes two or three more will follow by the end of the year.However, rather than the retail sector, Mr Ladha believes the beauty business will offer more long term security, not least because the new tenants are less likely to be in competition with the internet.ldquoWe want to attract tenants who probably already have their own clients ndash barbers, hairdressers, nail technicians and clinics, he said.ldquoI think it will work because a lot of businesses like this are normally on the first floor, but this will give them a chance to be on the ground floor in a busy city centre location and much more accessible.ldquoWe are spending money to bring people back to town.Earlier this month, the Inverness Courier highlighted the number of empty shop units in the city centre, with at least  lying empty in the Old Town area. However, the Highland capital compares favourably with other parts of the country with a vacancy rate of . per cent against the national average of  per cent.Tuesday  Nov  : PM

title: Outdoor adveture drive for tourist sector
story: UNLOCKING revenue from the untapped outdoor adventure market was the key theme of the Highland Tourism Conference at The Drumossie Hotel this week.More than  people attendedthe event which was sparked-off by keynote speaker and double gold Olympic medallist sailor and CNN broadcaster Shirley Robertson.The meeting, which comes after The Lonely Planet selected the Highlands and Islands amongst its Best in Travel for  ndash the only Scottish destinations to be included ndash carried a clear message: Give tourists what they are looking for: a spot of adventure in the fresh Highland air.Niche markets like sailing, or whisky and mountain-biking trails were highlighted as strong ideas that could ldquoextend the Scottish welcome and enhance that visitorrsquos inidual experience of the Highlands.Graeme Ambrose, chief executive of Visit Inverness Loch Ness who talked about LochNess , said all were agreed that maximising the potential of the outdoor and adventure markets is fundamental to a more sustainable Highland tourism industry.Other speakers included adventure cyclist Ed Shoote.Tuesday  Nov  : PM

title: Port appoints new environment expert
story: A BUSY port has appointed a new specialist to keep an eye on its environment.As environmental adviser for the Port of Cromarty Firth, Andrew Goldie will be responsible for all of the environmental aspects involved in its activities, including safeguarding the waters and protected sites and wildle within the firth.In addition to working with port users to reduce environmental risks and ensure all environmental legal requirements are being met, he will also identy areas for environmental improvement.Mr Goldie said: ldquoBy looking at all the portrsquos activities, I can review what the environmental impacts are likely to be. While working with other colleagues, we can jointly help to safeguard the Cromarty estuary and Invergordon itself.ldquoSuch improvements will hopefully result in a more efficient company which can better serve its customers and protect our environment.Tuesday  Nov  : PM

title: Search continues for top young photographers
story: THE deadline to find the arearsquos best young photographers has been extended until the end of the year.The Inverness Courier and Inverness Camera Club ndash which are both celebrating milestone anniversaries ndash have joined forces to launch a photographic competition.Aimed at eight to -year-olds, entrants are asked to submit an image depicting the theme, Inverness Past and Present.The winners will have their work published in the Courier and receive a voucher and framed print of their entry.The competition marks the th anniversary of the Courier while the camera club is celebrating its th anniversary.As part of its celebrations, the club is displaying membersrsquo past images at Eden Court Theatre in Inverness. They will be on show on the Flow Photofest Wall until January .But the club is also keen to encourage young photographers to show off their work.Digital entries for the young photographersrsquo competition will be accepted in the four age categories ndash eight to  years,  to ,  to  and  to .Just one entry per person will be allowed, although two images per entry will be accepted.The judging  will include Owen Cochrane, president of the camera club Matt Sillars, a lecturer in photography at Inverness College UHI Culloden Academy teacher Jen Hay and Philip Murray, news editor with Scottish Provincial Press, which publishes the Courier.The four winning entries in each category plus a selection of other images will be exhibited at the Upstairs Gallery in the offices of HRI Munro Architecture in Academy Street.Entries should be sent as a jpeg to YOYP@invernesscameraclub by December .Tuesday  Nov  : PM

title: boyle scores for aussies
story: Aberdeen-born ex-Montrose winger Martin Boyle has scored his first goals for Australia.Boyle, , was called up to the Socceroos by boss Graham Arnold after talks with the manager and with the blessing of Hibernian gaffer Neil Lennon.The Hibees star was playing today in a friendly against Lebanon, scoring the Aussies’ first two goals.On  minutes, Boyle smashed home right-footed from the edge of the area after a good run.His second, which came just before half-time, was an easier finish, the north-east player presented with an open goal after Australia hit the bar.Mat Leckie’s volley for the home side’s third was also the product of a Boyle cross in what was an emphatic debut.Of his eligibility to play for Arnold’s team, Boyle has previously said: “Apparently I am eligible through my dad being born in Australia andanything came about I’d probably grasp it with both hands.“If they were to know that I’m eligible then, who knows, they might have a look at me.“To play for any country would be a great honour and I have family in Australia.“Any international side would be a pleasure to play in.”The friendly also marked the farewell appearance of Australia’s greatest player, former Everton striker Tim Cahill.

title: aberdeen beach to be cleaned up following keep britain tidy vote
story: The date for an Aberdeen beach clean up has been announced.The beach at Torry Battery Beach won a competition led by general public’s vote to receive a beach litter pick on Thursday.Household brands Fairy, Head  Shoulders and Tesco stores teamed up with Keep Britain Tidy to facilitate beach cleans around the UK.Torry Battery was among the top  shorelines in the nation to receive the clean up – the other Scottish beach which won was at Broughty Ferry.The competition was part of Fairy and Head  Shoulders launching new bottles, made from up to % recycled plastic, including recovered beach plastics.

title: do you recognise this toy poodle called argyle he was found alone in aberdeen1
story: A toy poodle has been found wandering the streets of Aberdeen.Named Argyle, according to his microchip, the distressed dog was taken to Mrs Murray#s Cat and Dog home after he was found near Denmore Road.Due to the extent of matting, staff at the home had to clip the hair on his face so he could open his mouth and eat. vw, px"  Vets then had to completely shave him and he required extensive dental treatment.The Scottish SPCA were alerted by Mrs Murray#s Cat and Dog home due to his condition, with the charity now looking to trace his owners. vw, px"  Scottish SPCA Inspector Fiona McKenzie said: “Mrs Murray’s Cat and Dog Home contacted us because the toy poodle was so terribly matted when he came into their care.“They immediately had to clip his face just so he could open his mouth and eat properly.“He was then taken to a vet where his entire coat had to be shaved and he received extensive dental treatment.“A dog of this breed requires regular grooming and maintenance of their coat.“This is a duty a responsible owner should provide. vw, px"  “We are investigating the circumstances of his condition and hope the public can help us in identying his owner.“He is a -year-old, entire male toy poodle with the tip of his ear missing.“According to his microchip, his name is Argyle.“Unfortunately, his details are still registered to his breeder but he may have been rehomed previously in the Peterhead area.“If anyone recognises Argyle we’d urge them to contact us as we are keen to identy his owner.”

title: thousands turn out for christmas events across north east
story: Festive cheer is in the air after thousands of residents turned out to celebrate a north-east town#s Christmas lights switch-on.An early Christmas present was delivered to Ellon when the festive festivities began. vw, px"  Chairwoman of Ellon Community Council’s Christmas lights committee Julianna Gorska said about , people in the town took part in the festivities on Saturday.She said: “This is the first year the event was moved from Neil Ross Square to the Riverside car park.“Since Ellon is a growing town, we wanted a larger space where we can fit everyone.“We think there must have been about , people there.” vw, px"  Kicking off the festivities at am, the event saw a iety of entertainment, from a fire performance, Santa’s grotto, local music groups and a closing fireworks show at pm.Julianna added: “Everybody who has been posting on the Facebook page said they really enjoyed themselves – which is the main point.“We just wanted a family fun day where people could come out and enjoy themselves.”The town also saw a Christmas craft fair, a number of charity stalls and its annual parade. vw, px"  Meanwhile, Cults, Bieldside and Milltimber Community Council also celebrated its first-ever Christmas lights switch-on.Lindsay Davidson, a community councillor who was the driving force behind the plans, said she hoped the event could be an annual gathering for the residents.The thought originally came to Lindsay when she saw the quality of lights in other areas of the city.She said: “For our first event I was overwhelmed by its popularity, with more than  people attending.“I think it went really great and it was well attended – a great success.“During , I as a community councillor embarked on an ambitious Christmas Lights Project with the aim of introducing new festive lighting into our community.“We had no budget for this project, so I reached out to prominent local businesses and community stakeholders for sponsorship and were truly delighted to obtain sufficient sponsorship to fund our feature lights.“These are now mounted along the North Deeside Road.” vw, px"  MSP Maureen Watt and area councillors Marie Bolton and Mohammed Tauqeer Malik attended.More than  people gathered at the Hub Cafe in Cults Kirk Centre on Saturday, where guests enjoyed face-painting, stalls from local businesses and mulled wine.The community council secured sponsorship from local businesses, including Cala Homes, Bancon Homes and Esker Gin, to deck out  lamp-posts along North Deeside Road with festive lights.Lindsay added: “Entertainment was provided by Chorus of Sweet Adelines – and we even had a Santa arriving in his decorated TukTuk.“We had stalls featuring local businesses, with Childline also attending – Pantosaurus even delayed his trip back to Glasgow.“Special thanks to our elected representatives who took time out of their busy schedule to help on the day.“Also, huge thanks to everyone who volunteered on the day, who without, the event wouldn’t have happened.”

title: gemma retains tour card after soaking up pressure at pinehurst
story: Aberdonian Gemma Dryburgh retained her full LPGA status for  by finishing tied rd at the inaugural LPGA Q-Series at Pinehurst.After eight arduous rounds of intense pressure to maintain her status, Gemma finished four-over-par after rounds of , , , , , ,  and  for an aggregate of .Crucially, Gemma’s all-important final round ended on a high after she holed out from a bunker at the sixth for a birdie and she also holed a -yard chip at the last.Gemma, who is now attached to Beaconsfield, said: “I am so pleased to have regained my full LPGA tour card for the  seaso“It was a long two weeks of qualying and I am happy to see all of the hard work and preparation pay off.“After learning a lot as a rookie this year, I am looking forward to putting my experience to use during my second year.”The Q-Series, which had a field of  players, replaced Final Stage III qualying which was played annually at Daytona Beach.Gemma started playing golf when her father John introduced her to the sport aged four.She moved to Florida to go to IMG Academy aged  before attending Tulane University in New Orleans on a scholarship. Gemma played for Scotland in the World Amateur Championship in Japan, the Spirit International in the US, the European Team Championships, and in two South American Amateur Championships in Colombia and Peru.The highlight of her amateur career was playing for GBI in the  Curtis Cup in St Louis, Missouri.After finishing at Tulane, Gemma turned professional and secured main tour playing rights on both sides of the Atlantic before winning her first pro event in Sydney, Australia, earlier this year.
